row.column: Inventory Management The Inventory module provides a wide range of add-on features which will help your business to more effectively manage the inventory. With the basic functionality only, you can create and maintain stock and non-stock items, update prices and evaluate costs, perform receipts and issues, prepare and complete full physical counts. The add-on features enable you to track items by lot or serial numbers and expiration dates; use multiple units of measure (base, sales, and purchase units) for each item and configure the rules for conversion between these units of measure; configure multiple warehouses, each with multiple locations; set up automated replenishment; configure automatic packaging to facilitate shipping; and more. The Inventory module is integrated with the financial modules, as well as with other modules of the inventory and order management. This part of the Inventory Management Guide contains all the information you need to use the Inventory module. In This Guide Overview of the Inventory ProcessesManaging WarehousesConfiguring Basic InventoryManaging Inventory KitsManaging Hierarchical Item ClassesManaging Item Cross-ReferencesManaging Inventory Item AttributesManaging Lot and Serial NumbersManaging SubitemsProcessing Inventory TransactionsConfiguring Basic Inventory ProcessesConfiguring Advanced Physical InventoryReviewing CostsCounting Physical InventoryClosing Inventory PeriodsReplenishing Inventory ItemsInventory Form ReferenceInventory Reports

Overview of the Inventory Processes The Inventory module provides real-time access to stock item availability data configured in accordance with your company's policies. By using the Inventory module, you can maintain a perpetual inventory system while also performing physical inventories as full inventory counts and counts by cycles. In Acumatica ERP, you can track items by either lot or serial numbers, as well as by expiration dates. By using multiple valuation methods, you can accurately maintain item costs and trace cost flows. By using flexible posting settings, you can meet any regulatory requirements. The full functionality of the Inventory module is available only if the Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Stock and Non-Stock Inventory Items Inventory items are the goods, products, services, and component parts recorded to and tracked in your system database. Inventory items can be divided into two major categories, stock and non-stock items, based on how they are handled and accounted for. By using functionality of restriction groups, you can control visibility of particular inventory items to employees. For more information, see the following topics: Inventory ItemsStock ItemsNon-Stock Items in the Inventory ModuleInventory Item SecurityFlexible Item Identifiers and Support of Alternative IDs By using configurable inventory IDs, you can uniquely identify inventory items. If you use subitems in your system, you can further subdivide items by size, color, material, and other criteria that apply to your business. You can easily gather additional business-specific data about inventory items by configuring custom fields, called attributes . Also, on purchase and sales orders, you can use barcodes or vendor or customer alternative IDs to find items or record item information. For more information, see the following topics: Inventory SubitemsInventory Item AttributesItem Cross-ReferencesBarcode SupportGlobal and Item-Specific UOMs You can use an unlimited number of units of measure (UOMs) in your system. Commonly used units of measure—liters, gallons, pounds, and kilograms—can be defined globally and then used as base units of measure for specific item classes or particular products. You can define conversion rules between UOMs (such as pounds and kilograms). You can specify UOMs and conversion rules at the item-class and item level—cases or boxes intended for different products can be of different capacities. Once you have defined conversion rules, the system automatically makes conversions to the correct unit of measure when necessary. If the Multiple Units of Measure feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, for each item you can define, in addition to the base unit, the purchase UOM to be used to measure item quantity on purchase orders and receipts and the sales unit to measure the item quantities on sales orders and invoices. Prices for base UOMs and sales UOMs can be set as independent prices, if needed. For more information, see Units of Measure and Conversions. Multiple Warehouses and Locations In Acumatica ERP, you can maintain a complex warehouse structure, defining multiple warehouses with multiple locations within each. This functionality is available if you enable the Multiple Warehouses and Multiple Warehouse Locations features on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. By configuring segmentation for location identifiers, you can maintain a hierarchy of rooms, rows, levels, shelves, bins, and other divisions. For each location, you can define which inventory operations can be performed there. You can also specify a primary inventory item or primary item class, and set up validation so that if a preferred item is specified and the validation is turned on, only the preferred item can be received at the location. By using security functionality, you can restrict the visibility of warehouse information to groups of authorized users. For more information, see the following topics: Warehouses in Acumatica ERPMultiple WarehousesWarehouse LocationsWarehouse SecurityFlexible Posting Settings You can set up the system to automatically update the General Ledger on release of inventory documents. Posting classes assigned to inventory items define the rules for selecting particular General Ledger accounts and subaccounts to be updated when transactions with the items are performed. Reason codes for inventory transactions provide the offset accounts to be updated, depending on the type of inventory transactions. For more information, see the following topics: Posting Settings in the Inventory ModulePosting Classes in InventoryReason Codes for InventoryInventory Transactions The Inventory module supports the following types of documents, recording the same-name inventory transactions: receipt, issue, adjustment, transfer, and kit assembly. Inventory documents facilitate accounting for transactions that result in changing inventory quantities and costs. For more information about inventory transactions, see Inventory Transactions. Availability Calculation Acumatica ERP provides real-time visibility into the available inventory levels. The way availability data is calculated can be configured in accordance with the policies set in your company. Availability calculation rules are specified for item classes. You can create multiple rules with different calculation settings and assign them to different item classes. The availability data of items is shown on sales orders, purchase orders, and kit assemblies. For more information, see Availability Calculation. Lot and Serial Number Tracking With the Inventory module, you can track stock items by lot or serial numbers and by expiration dates if the Lot and Serial Tracking feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form. Acumatica ERP provides flexible numbering schemes for lot and serial numbers, and the ability to track different products differently. For more information about the use of lot and serial numbers, see the following topics: Lot and Serial NumbersLot and Serial Number TrackingKit Assembling Some stock or non-stock items may be kits made up of other inventory items. Non-stock kits can include both non-stock and stock components and are not recorded in the Inventory module. Stock components of non-stock kits are processed as if they are managed separately not within a kit. Stock kits also can include both stock and non-stock components but are recorded in the Inventory module and are regarded as individual items. For more information about kits, see Inventory Item Kits. Inventory Valuation By using a perpetual inventory system, which Acumatica ERP enables, your company can estimate the total cost of its inventory at any moment, because on-hand quantities and inventory account balances are updated with every transaction, purchase, or sale. Periodic revision of standard costs for items with standard cost valuation methods results in the revaluation of the cost of inventory. Periodic updates of base prices can be performed automatically. For more information on inventory valuation, see the following topics: The Cost of InventoryItem Costs and Valuation MethodsDefault PricesPhysical Inventories By using Acumatica ERP, your company can maintain a perpetual inventory system with the combination of full physical inventory and cycle counting that best fits the company policies and goals. Count data can be imported from Excel files or entered manually by multiple employees working simultaneously on multiple computers. The information from these counts provides company managers with exact values of stock levels. For more information, see the following topics: Configuration of Physical InventoryTypes of Physical InventoryCycle Counting ConfigurationInventory Ranking MethodsConfiguration of Physical Inventory Counts by ABC CodesPhysical Inventory CountsPreparation for Physical CountAutomated Replenishment In Acumatica ERP, you can configure automated replenishment of stock items. Flexible, automated replenishment ensures that for items requiring replenishment, the right quantities will be calculated and listed on automatically generated purchase orders. Moreover, you can use the predicted average daily demand, calculated with the help of demand forecasting methods, to periodically update the values of replenishment parameters (such as maximum quantity, reorder point, and safety stock) to more precisely calculate the quantities required for replenishment. For more information, see the following topics: Configuration of Automated ReplenishmentAutomated ReplenishmentReplenishment Methods and Their ParametersReplenishment Parameters Based on Demand Forecast Financial Period Closing in the Inventory module When accountants close financial periods in the system, they must close periods in all modules that your Acumatica ERP instance uses. Before closing periods in the Inventory module you have to review all unprocessed transactions and process or delete them. For more information, see the following topics: Financial Period Closing in the Inventory ModuleReconciliation of the Cost of Inventory with the Account BalanceOther Features and Options The Inventory module also provides the following features: The ability to quickly add product images to the inventory item record. Tracking of items by product workgroup or product manager. Item availability data displayed when you create a sales or a purchase order. The ability to print count sheets, tags, and item and location labels, to facilitate the counting process. For perishable items, tracking of expiration dates, with alerts displayed about expired items. The ability to set up the automatic issue of items by expiration date. Segmented identifiers for locations, to make it easier to locate stock. By using segments, you can define further detail levels of locations, such as rooms, shelves, and bins.

row.PlainText: Managing Warehouses In Acumatica ERP, you can manage warehouses in the way that best fits your business—by configuring a single warehouse or multiple warehouses, and by defining multiple locations within any warehouse. Depending on the extent of your inventory and warehouse operations, you can configure as warehouses actual warehouses, storerooms, or service vehicles, and you can configure as warehouse locations such places as aisles, shelves, storerooms, or service vehicles. Also, you can reserve dedicated warehouse locations for specific inventory transactions, such as receipts, issues, and returns. In this chapter, you can find information about warehouses and warehouse locations. In This Chapter Warehouses in Acumatica ERPMultiple WarehousesWarehouse LocationsWarehouse SecurityTo Create a WarehouseTo Create Warehouse LocationsTo Use Warehouse General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts in a Posting Class

row.column: Warehouses in Acumatica ERPIf your organization keeps any physical items on site that are currently unused but expected to be used or sold, it uses storage for these items. Your storage can be as small as a shelf with dozens of office supplies in a back office or as large as multiple physical warehouses with billions of goods situated in different regions or even countries. If you want to track your stored items in Acumatica ERP, you can use the functionality of warehouses and locations and choose the approach that best fits your business. You can configure a single warehouse or multiple warehouses. Within each warehouse, you can define a single location or multiple locations. In this topic, you will find general information about warehouses in Acumatica ERP. Warehouses in Acumatica ERPIn Acumatica ERP, a warehouse does not necessarily represent a physical building where your inventory is stocked. You can divide a large physical storage space into multiple areas and define each area as a warehouse in Acumatica ERP. A warehouse can even be virtual: for example, you might consider all goods that are on the way from the supplier to you as being located in a goods-in-transit warehouse. You can configure any of the following warehouse structures: One warehouse with one location: You use this structure when you have a small variety of inventory items and it’s not important for you to track in which room or on which shelf these items are stored. For more information, see Basic Warehouse Structure Basic Warehouse Structure. One warehouse with multiple locations: You use this structure when you have one space and need to track the locations within it and the items in those locations. For example, you might have one physical room with many numbered shelves, or multiple rooms with shelves and boxes, and you may want to register in the system the exact placement of each inventory item. Multiple warehouses with one location in each warehouse: You use this structure when you store items in multiple physical rooms or buildings, and each storage place holds a small number of items, which warehouse employees can easily find without knowing a more specific location of items. Multiple warehouses with multiple locations in each warehouse: You use this structure when you have a distributed network of large warehouses that hold a wide variety of goods in different locations. Multiple warehouses with one location or multiple locations in each warehouse: You use this structure when you have multiple warehouses, which vary in terms of whether they have multiple locations within them. For example, when you have a large distribution center from where goods are sent to multiple small warehouses. For more information, see Multiple Warehouses and Warehouse Locations. Basic Warehouse Structure When you have just a few items to keep in a small storage area, you can use the basic functionality of warehouses in Acumatica ERP. The basic functionality is available when you have the following license settings on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form: The Inventory feature is enabled. The Multiple Warehouses and Multiple Warehouse Locations features (which provide more advanced functionality) are disabled. The system creates the default warehouse and assigns MAIN as the warehouse ID when you configure the settings of the Inventory module on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. The ID of the only warehouse, MAIN , is not displayed on data entry forms for simplicity. However, this warehouse ID will be used automatically in all inventory transactions. If needed, you can change the identifier of the MAIN warehouse on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form by clicking Actions Change ID on the form toolbar and specifying a new identifier in the dialog box that opens. When the Multiple Warehouses feature is not enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form displays only the Warehouse ID box. The following settings are specified for the default warehouse but are hidden from this form: Replenishment Class : Purchase Default Cost of Returns : Average For the default warehouse, the system creates a default location that the goods will be received to and issued from and assigns MAIN as the location ID. The location settings are not displayed on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form if the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form, but the MAIN location has the following settings: Active : Selected Include in Qty. Available : Selected Cost Separately : Cleared Sales Allowed : Selected Receipts Allowed : Selected Transfers Allowed : Selected Assembly Allowed : Selected ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000])

Multiple Warehouses When your organization has multiple buildings, storage rooms, or other facilities for storing inventory items, you can create multiple warehouses in Acumatica ERP to process inventory appropriately for each warehouse. With the Multiple Warehouses feature enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can create any number of warehouses, even virtual warehouses, in the way that best fits your business with specific settings for each warehouse. In this topic, you will read about multiple warehouses in Acumatica ERP. Configuration of Multiple Warehouses After you have enabled the Multiple Warehouses feature on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form and configured inventory preferences (see Configuration of Basic Inventory), you can create as many warehouses as you need on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form. In Acumatica ERP, if you have multiple warehouses defined, you can perform transfers between warehouses, relocating stock items as needed, or you can use one warehouse as a source of replenishment for other warehouses by having purchased goods delivered to only this warehouse and then transferring the goods to other warehouses. To create and configure a warehouse, you do the following: Optional: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS202000|CS202000]) Segmented Keys (CS202000) form, you review the default settings of the INSITE segmented key, which is used for warehouse identifiers, and adjust the settings of the key to meet your needs. You can configure identifiers to have one segment or multiple segments. If you are going to use multiple segments, you need to determine how many segments (and of what length) will be used, whether the segments should be validated (and if so, what kind of values are allowed), and whether an auto-numbered segment will be used. For details on segmented keys, see Segmented Identifiers. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form, you create a warehouse and specify its settings, as described in To Create a Warehouse. If you want to specify warehouse-specific General Ledger accounts, make sure that all the necessary accounts have been created in the system before you start creating warehouses. Optional: On the Location Table tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form, you specify the locations for the warehouse. For more information about warehouse locations, see Warehouse Locations. The Location Table tab is displayed on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form only if the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form. Optional: You configure warehouse security, such as restricting access to forms based on user roles and configuring the visibility of particular warehouses to appropriate users. For details, see Warehouse Security. Warehouse as a Source of GL Accounts and Subaccounts for Posting Classes A posting class, which is specified for each stock or non-stock item, is a group of settings that provide the default values for the purchase, sales, and inventory transactions with the item and define how these transactions will be posted to the General Ledger. One of these default values is the source of General Ledger accounts and subaccounts to be used for the item, which can be a source of default General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for an inventory item. If you store inventory items of the same category in multiple warehouses, and each warehouse has specific General Ledger accounts and subaccounts specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form, you can use a warehouse as a source of default General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for an inventory item. You define the source of accounts and subaccounts that the system should use in a posting class. For example, you can have one inventory account for each warehouse. In this case, you can specify the needed inventory account in the warehouse settings on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form and specify the warehouse as the source of inventory account in the posting class on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form. For details about how to specify a warehouse as a source of General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for a posting class, see To Use Warehouse General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts in a Posting Class. Warehouse-Specific Settings for Stock Items If the details of stocking a particular inventory item vary in different warehouses, you specify the details for the item at each warehouse on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. You can view these warehouse-specific settings of items on the Warehouse Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. For each stock item at a particular warehouse, you can specify the following: The default locations for issuing and receiving the item at this warehouse The inventory account and subaccount to be used for the stock item at this warehouse The ABC code and movement class assigned to the item when it is at this warehouse The replenishment settings for the item when it is stocked in this warehouse The cost statistics related to this item at this warehouse In the following cases, the system adds a new record to the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form: When any user specifies or changes the default warehouse for an inventory item on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. When any user releases the first inventory receipt to a new warehouse (or other transaction that increases inventory, such as the receiving part of an inventory transfer). Warehouse-Specific Prices If you have multiple warehouses defined in the system, you can define warehouse-specific sales prices and vendor prices for items. You can define the price of the item and select the warehouse for this price. If no warehouse is specified for a price on the ([~/?ScreenId=AP202010|AP202010]) Vendor Price Worksheets (AP202010) or ([~/?ScreenId=AR202000|AR202000]) Sales Prices (AR202000) forms, this price is applied to all warehouses that are defined in the system. A price that has a warehouse specified has a higher priority than a price of the same type with no warehouse selected. For example, a promotional customer price that is specific to a warehouse has a higher priority than a promotional customer price with no warehouse specified. For more information, see Multiple Price Lists and Maintaining Vendor Price Lists. Warehouse Locations In Acumatica ERP, you can configure multiple locations in each warehouse to best fit the logistics established in your company. You can reserve specific locations for sales, receipts, transfers, goods to be returned to vendors, and goods returned by customers. You can assign different pick priorities to locations, to empty certain locations more quickly while using others less frequently. In this topic, you will find information about the creation and use of warehouse locations in Acumatica ERP. Default Warehouse Locations For each warehouse created in the system, the system automatically creates a default location (with the MAIN location ID, which you can change later) that the goods will be received to and issued from. The MAIN location has the following settings on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form: Active : Selected Include in Qty. Available : Selected Cost Separately : Cleared Sales Allowed : Selected Receipts Allowed : Selected Transfers Allowed : Selected Assembly Allowed : Selected These location settings are displayed on the Location Table tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form only if the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form; if it is not enabled, the tab is not shown on the form but the settings listed above are used internally. Configuration of Warehouse Locations With the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can configure multiple locations for each warehouse. If it is enabled, on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form, you can view and change the settings of the default location and define the other locations for each warehouse. You do the following to create and configure warehouse locations in Acumatica ERP: Optional: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS202000|CS202000]) Segmented Keys (CS202000) form, you review the structure of the INLOCATION segmented key, which defines the identifiers for warehouse locations. If you want to create a hierarchy of locations (site, aisle, pallet, bin, and so forth), you can configure location identifiers that consist of multiple segments, with each segment denoting a specific level in this hierarchy. For example, suppose that you have three racks, each with four shelves, in a warehouse. A location identifier can look as follows: Rn-SHm , where Rn is the number of the rack (such as R2 ) and SHm is the number of the shelf in the rack (such as SH4 ). For more information about segmented keys, see Segmented Identifiers. On the Location Table tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form for each warehouse, you add each location and specify its settings, as described in To Create Warehouse Locations. You add as many locations as you need. To create similar configurations of locations in multiple warehouses, you can export the location table to an Excel file (with the .xlsx format) and import settings from the file to the same warehouse or another warehouse and change the setting as needed. For details on importing the settings from an Excel file, see Integration with Excel. Optional: On the Location Table tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form, you specify the default locations (which simplify data entry on purchase receipts and sales orders) for inventory operations in the following boxes: Receiving Location : The default receiving location for stock items in the warehouse. Shipping Location : The default shipping location for the warehouse. RMA Location : The location used for all operations involving return merchandise authorization (RMA). The returned goods will be delivered to the location specified in this box, regardless of the warehouse location selected by default for the receipt of these goods. Drop-Ship Location : The location used for drop-ship orders and all inventory documents that are automatically generated for drop-ship orders. Optional: In the Location Entry box in the Summary area of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form, you specify the option that indicates whether you want to allow users to add new locations on the fly when they are entering inventory documents. You can view locations added by users on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form and modify their settings if needed. Priorities of Warehouse Locations If you store inventory items of the same type (such as apples) in multiple locations within the same warehouse, the system has to find the appropriate warehouse location from which to pick the items when a user creates a shipment for a sales order. For each location, you can specify the pick priority, which will help the system to select a correct location if it finds multiple locations that have the item. For example, suppose that you store a dairy product with that can be kept for one week. You purchase this dairy product every day and store it in two locations of the warehouse: A and B. In Location A, you store a variant of the dairy product that can be kept from five to seven days. In Location B, you store a variant of the dairy produce that can be kept from two to four days. You can assign the highest pick priority to Location B so that dairy product with an earlier expiration date are shipped first. The way the system finds a location from which the line item's ordered quantity will be picked depends on whether the applicable sales order is related to a project and task and on the location settings—whether the Project ID and Task ID columns are filled in for the location on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form—as follows: If the sales order is not related to any project: The system searches for the applicable location among all available locations and selects the location with the highest pick priority. If the sales order is related to a project and a task—that is, if a project ID is specified for the sales order on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) form and a task ID is specified for a sales order line on this form): The system selects the first applicable location it finds by using the following search priority (from highest to lowest): A location for which the project ID and task ID are the same as the project ID and task ID of the sales order A location whose project ID is the same as the project ID of the sales order and whose task ID is unspecified A location for which the project ID and task ID are not specified A location for which the project ID is the same as the project ID of a sales order and for which the task ID differs from the task ID of the sales order line If both sales orders related to projects and sales orders unrelated to projects are used in your system, and you want to ensure that locations in shipments match project codes in sales orders, we recommend that you specify the lowest pick priority (that is, the highest value in the Pick Priority column on the Location Table tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form) for those locations that are associated with projects. As a result, for the sales orders that are unrelated to projects, the system will search among the non-project locations first; if no applicable non-project location has been found, the system will continue to search in the locations that are related to projects.

Warehouse Security An organization can have multiple warehouses in Acumatica ERP, and different groups of employees may work with these warehouses in the system. To limit in the system the set of employees who work with a particular warehouse, you can create restriction groups to display the warehouse for only employees who are responsible for tasks that involve this warehouse. If the employees who work with the same warehouse perform only specific tasks (such as accepting goods and creating purchase orders), you can provide these employees with access to only the forms that they should use. In this topic, you can find information about configuring the security of warehouses in Acumatica ERP. In Acumatica ERP, you can configure groups with direct and inverse restriction. In this topic, for simplicity, groups with direct restriction are used in examples. You can use inverse restriction groups in the same way as you use direct restriction groups. For details on the types of restriction groups, see Types of Restriction Groups. Usage Scenarios The most common scenarios of managing the security of warehouses are the following: Managing access to forms based on employees' functional roles: If employees perform specific tasks (such as receiving goods and creating purchase orders), you can provide the employees access to the forms they use in their work, and revoke access for forms that they shouldn't use. For details, see Access to Forms Based on Roles Access to Forms Based on Roles. Managing the visibility of particular warehouses by user: If you have created multiple warehouses in Acumatica ERP, you can restrict the visibility of warehouses to users on forms by using restriction groups. For details, see Visibility of Warehouses by User Visibility of Warehouses by User. You can create and manage multiple warehouses in Acumatica ERP only if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. In addition to managing the visibility of warehouses in whole, you can restrict the visibility of particular inventory items. For details, see Inventory Item Security. Access to Forms Based on Roles By using the forms of the User Security submodule, you can use user roles in Acumatica ERP to give employees access to forms related to working with warehouses. A role can correspond to an area of responsibility for an employee who performs warehouse-related tasks, such as creating purchase orders, accepting goods, and preparing replenishment. If needed, you can assign multiple roles to an employee. For more information about user roles, see Role-Based Access. Consider the following examples of roles for employees who work with inventory and order management: Supervisor : A role for an employee who configures the Inventory submodule and manages work with the submodule. This role should have access to the forms related to inventory processes, such as the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. Data Entry Clerk : A role for an employee who creates documents on data entry forms. You should provide access to such forms as ([~/?ScreenId=IN302000|IN302000]) Issues (IN302000), ([~/?ScreenId=IN301000|IN301000]) Receipts (IN301000), or ([~/?ScreenId=IN304000|IN304000]) Transfers (IN304000). Purchasing Manager : A role for an employee who is responsible for replenishment. For this role, you should provide access to the Replenishment node of the Processes tab of the Inventory module. Visibility of Warehouses by User By default, all employees who have access to forms of the inventory and order management modules can see all warehouses created in the system. By using the forms of the Row-Level Security module, you can configure the system so that each warehouse is displayed only to users who work with this warehouse. You can use restriction groups to set up the visibility of warehouses to employees. For details on restriction groups, see Restriction Groups in Acumatica ERP. For example, suppose that your system has the Wholesale and Retail warehouses defined, and you need to configure the visibility of these warehouses to users as follows: User S is a supervisor who should configure and manage both warehouses. User C1 is a clerk who enters documents for the Wholesale warehouse. User C2 is a clerk who enters documents for the Retail warehouse. To configure the visibility of warehouses according to this example, you do the following on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN102000|IN102000]) Warehouse Access (IN102000) form: You create two restriction groups of type A (with direct restriction): Group 1 for the Wholesale warehouse, and Group 2 for the Retail warehouse. In Group 1, you include User S, User C1, and the Wholesale warehouse. In Group 2, you include User S, User C2, and the Retail warehouse. The resulting visibility of warehouses will be the following: User S can see both the Wholesale and Retail warehouses. User C1 can see only the Wholesale warehouse. User C2 can see only the Retail warehouse. Forms for Warehouse Security In the following table, you can find the list of forms that you can use to manage restriction groups with warehouses and tasks that you can solve by using each form. Forms for Warehouse Security Tasks Forms To initially configure the visibility of a warehouse to users ([~/?ScreenId=IN102000|IN102000]) Warehouse Access (IN102000) To change the visibility of a warehouse in multiple restriction groups ([~/?ScreenId=IN102010|IN102010]) Restriction Groups by Warehouse (IN102010) To change the visibility of warehouses to a user in multiple restriction groups ([~/?ScreenId=SM201035|SM201035]) Restriction Groups by User (SM201035) For information about how to add or remove objects from a restriction group, see Operations with Restriction Groups. To Create a Warehouse When your organization uses multiple warehouses to store inventory items, you can create these warehouses in the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form. In this topic, you will read how to create a warehouse with a single location, which is the case when the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. If you want to have multiple locations, you need to complete these steps and then refer to To Create Warehouse Locations for details on adding locations. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Make sure that the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. To Create a Warehouse Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Warehouse ID box, type the unique identifier to be used for the warehouse. If your company uses multiple branches, in the Branch box, select the branch to which the warehouse will belong. Optional: On the GL Accounts tab, select warehouse-specific General Ledger accounts and subaccounts (if applicable). To Create Warehouse Locations If you want to track inventory items by their exact location in the particular warehouse, you can create any number of warehouse locations in the system by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form, as described in this topic. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Make sure that the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. To Create a Warehouse Location Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Warehouse ID box, select the warehouse for which you want to create a location. On the Location Table tab, do the following for each location you need to create in the selected warehouse: On the table toolbar of the Location table, click Add Row . In the Location ID column of the added row, type the unique location identifier to be used for this location. In the other columns, check the default location settings and change them if necessary. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

To Use Warehouse General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts in a Posting Class If you use multiple warehouses in Acumatica ERP, you can configure a warehouse as a source for General Ledger accounts and subaccounts (if they are used in your system) for inventory items that are stored in multiple warehouses and if each warehouse has its specific accounts and subaccounts. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. To Use Warehouse General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts in a Posting Class Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form by searching for or navigating to it. On the form, do the following: In the Warehouse ID box, select warehouse that you will use as a source of accounts and subaccounts for a posting class. On the GL Accounts tab, specify the accounts and subaccounts that the system should use from the warehouse in the posting class. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form by searching for or navigating to it. On the form, do the following: In the Class ID box of the Summary area, select a posting class for which you want to specify a warehouse as a source of General Ledger accounts and subaccounts. On the Posting Settings tab, select Warehouse in each box related to an entity for which you want to use General Ledger accounts and subaccounts from the warehouse (such as the Use Inventory/Accrual Account from box). On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

Before you start using the inventory functionality in Acumatica ERP, you need to specify basic settings, as described in this topic. ==Configuration of Basic Inventory== Before you start configuring the Inventory module, you make sure that the following is done in the system:[anchor|#_6691133e-62ec-4f5c-9d92-6ebe91ce9171] *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form, the ''Inventory'' feature under the ''Standard Inventory'' group of features are enabled. By enabling these features, you activate the basic functionality of the following modules: **Inventory **Purchase Orders **Sales Orders *:The basic functionality provides one default warehouse, and gives you the ability to configure purchase order processing for regular orders and configure sales order processing with predefined order types. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\GL_20_25_00|Chart of Accounts] ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) form, all General Ledger accounts that you will use for inventory have been added. For details, see [HelpRoot_Financials\GL__CON_Chart_of_Accounts|Chart of Accounts]. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_21_10_00|Reason Codes] ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) form, all reason codes that you will use for inventory have been added. For more information, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Reason_Codes__Definition_and_Usage|Reason Codes for Inventory]. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_20_10_10|Numbering Sequences] ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) form, all numbering sequences for batches, receipts, issues, adjustments, and physical inventory documents have been added. For details, see [HelpRoot_Administration\CS__con_Multiple_Numbering_Sequences|Numbering Sequence Usage]. *:((({S:Hint}We recommend that in your production systems, for different types of inventory entries, you specify numbering sequences that differ at least by the prefix in the number. For example, you can use identifiers such as R0000001 for inventory receipts and I0000001 for inventory issues. The reference number of an inventory entry is recorded into the General Ledger transaction that is generated from the entry. When you use unique reference numbers between inventory entries, you can more easily audit the General Ledger transactions. )))
You do the following to configure the Inventory module in Acumatica ERP:[anchor|#_e153756e-f2d7-4f8f-9f6f-3fb0ba37b502] *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_10_10_00|Inventory Preferences] ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) form, you specify the settings of the Inventory module: numbering sequences, accounts, posting settings, data entry settings, reason codes, and physical inventory settings. The actual combination of settings you need to specify depends on the inventory processes in your organization and features enabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form. See [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__how_Specify_Bacis_Inventory_Preferences|To Specify Basic Inventory Preferences]. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_60_00|Posting Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) form, you create the necessary posting classes. For details, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Posting_Classes__Definition_and_Usage|Posting Classes in Inventory]. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_20_31_00|Units of Measure] ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) form, you add all necessary units of measure that you will use for inventory items. For details, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Units_of_Measure_and_Conversions|Units of Measure and Conversions]. *Optional: On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_15_00|Companies] ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) form, you specify the default units of measure for weight and volume. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_15_00|Availability Calculation Rules] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) form, you create calculation rules according to your inventory control requirements. For details, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Availability_Calculation|Availability Calculation]. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_10_00|Item Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) form, you create classes for inventory items, which you will enter into the system. For details, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Item_Classes|Item Classes]. *On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_25_00|Stock Items] ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) form, you create stock items. For details, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Stock_Items|Stock Items]. *Optional: On the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_20_00|Non-Stock Items] ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) form, you create non-stock items that you will process within the Inventory module. For details, see [HelpRoot_InvMgmt\IN__con_Non-Stock_Item_Support|Non-Stock Items in the Inventory Module].

Configuration of Basic Inventory Before you start using the inventory functionality in Acumatica ERP, you need to specify basic settings, as described in this topic. Configuration of Basic Inventory Before you start configuring the Inventory module, you make sure that the following is done in the system: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, the Inventory feature under the Standard Inventory group of features are enabled. By enabling these features, you activate the basic functionality of the following modules: Inventory Purchase Orders Sales Orders The basic functionality provides one default warehouse, and gives you the ability to configure purchase order processing for regular orders and configure sales order processing with predefined order types. On the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form, all General Ledger accounts that you will use for inventory have been added. For details, see Chart of Accounts. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form, all reason codes that you will use for inventory have been added. For more information, see Reason Codes for Inventory. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form, all numbering sequences for batches, receipts, issues, adjustments, and physical inventory documents have been added. For details, see Numbering Sequence Usage. We recommend that in your production systems, for different types of inventory entries, you specify numbering sequences that differ at least by the prefix in the number. For example, you can use identifiers such as R0000001 for inventory receipts and I0000001 for inventory issues. The reference number of an inventory entry is recorded into the General Ledger transaction that is generated from the entry. When you use unique reference numbers between inventory entries, you can more easily audit the General Ledger transactions. You do the following to configure the Inventory module in Acumatica ERP: On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form, you specify the settings of the Inventory module: numbering sequences, accounts, posting settings, data entry settings, reason codes, and physical inventory settings. The actual combination of settings you need to specify depends on the inventory processes in your organization and features enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. See To Specify Basic Inventory Preferences. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form, you create the necessary posting classes. For details, see Posting Classes in Inventory. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form, you add all necessary units of measure that you will use for inventory items. For details, see Units of Measure and Conversions. Optional: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies (CS101500) form, you specify the default units of measure for weight and volume. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form, you create calculation rules according to your inventory control requirements. For details, see Availability Calculation. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, you create classes for inventory items, which you will enter into the system. For details, see Item Classes. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you create stock items. For details, see Stock Items. Optional: On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, you create non-stock items that you will process within the Inventory module. For details, see Non-Stock Items in the Inventory Module.

Posting Settings in the Inventory Module An important part of the configuration of the Inventory module is to specify the posting settings—that is, the General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for inventory entities (such as stock items) and the rules determining how the system will select an account in specific transactions. In Acumatica ERP, you can create posting classes and reason codes that provide the default General Ledger accounts and subaccounts, or you can use warehouse- or item-specific accounts and subaccounts. In this topic, you will find information about the types of accounts used in the Inventory module, the system entities for which you can define accounts and subaccounts, and the posting settings. Configuration of Posting Settings Before you start configuring the Inventory module, you must create all necessary General Ledger accounts and subaccounts that the system will use for inventory transactions. For the description of the accounts and subaccounts used in inventory, see General Ledger Accounts in Inventory General Ledger Accounts in Inventory. During the configuration of the Inventory module, you specify the following posting settings: Reason codes: Reason codes are used with manually entered inventory transactions to track the reasons for these transactions. Reason codes provide offset accounts (with offset subaccounts if they are used in your system) to be used to post the transactions to General Ledger. For details, see Reason Codes Reason Codes. Posting classes: Posting classes are used to provide default General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for inventory items. For details, see Posting Classes Posting Classes. Integration settings between General Ledger and Inventory: The settings used to configure the level of integration between the Inventory and General Ledger modules. For details, see Inventory–General Ledger Integration Settings Inventory–General Ledger Integration Settings. We recommend that you thoroughly plan inventory accounts during the initial configuration of the Inventory module. But in rare situations you may need to change the accounts after users have started processing inventory documents. For more information, see Change of an Inventory Account for an Item Change of an Inventory Account for an Item. General Ledger Accounts in Inventory In the Inventory module, you can specify General Ledger accounts in settings of the following entities: warehouses (if you use multiple warehouses in the system), posting classes (which can be used for stock or non-stock items), stock items, and non-stock items. You can use the following General Ledger accounts to record inventory transactions: Inventory/Accrual account: An account that is one of the following: An asset account to keep the inventory balance resulting from transactions with a stock item (if the account is specified for a stock item or for a posting class used for a stock item) or transactions in a specific warehouse (if the account is specified in the warehouse settings). The cost of the items will be debited to the inventory account when the items are received, and credited when the items are issued from inventory. A liability account to be used for non-stock items as the expense accrual account (if the account is specified for a non-stock item or for a posting class to be used for non-stock items). The cost of purchased non-stock items will be credited to this account, and when a bill is created, the cost will be debited to this account. Sales account: The income account to record sales for a warehouse, posting class, stock item, or non-stock item. COGS/Expense account: An account that is one of the following: If the account is specified for a warehouse, stock item, or posting class for stock items, an expense account used as the cost of goods sold (COGS) account. This account will accrue the cost of goods sold once a sales order is released. The cost of items sold is debited to the account when items are issued for sale from inventory. If the account is specified for a non-stock item or for a posting class to be used for non-stock items or labor items, this is the expense account used for transactions with these items. Standard Cost Variance account: The expense account to be used for a warehouse, stock item, or posting class for stock items to record any differences between the currently effective standard cost and the cost on the bill for the specified quantities of items. This account is used only for transactions associated with inventory items for which the standard cost valuation method is assigned. Standard Cost Revaluation account: The expense account to be used for a warehouse, stock item, or posting class for stock items to record the differences in inventory value estimated by using the pending standard cost and the currently effective standard cost for the quantities on hand of a stock item. Revaluation is performed at the moment of updating standard costs—that is, when the currently effective standard cost becomes the last standard cost, and the pending cost becomes the effective standard cost. This account is used only for transactions associated with inventory items for which the standard cost valuation method is assigned. PO accrual account: The liability account to be used for a warehouse, stock item, or posting class to accrue amounts on purchase orders related to the warehouse or stock item. Whenever receipts linked to purchase orders are released, the system generates transactions between the purchase order accrual account and the inventory account. Purchase Price Variance account: The expense account to be used for a warehouse, stock item, non-stock item, or posting class for a stock or non-stock item to record any differences between the extended price on the purchase receipt and the extended price on the Accounts Payable bill. This account is used only for transactions associated with inventory items for which any of the valuation methods except for the standard cost valuation method is assigned. Landed Cost Variance account: The expense account to be used for a warehouse, stock item, or posting class for a stock item to record any differences in landed costs between the landed costs amounts specified on purchase receipts and the amounts on inventory receipts. Deferral account: The account to be used to hold the deferred amount until it is fully recognized. The account type should be specified as follows: A liability account for a deferral code of the revenue type An asset account for a deferral code of the expense type Reason Codes If inventory transactions are generated from the Purchase Orders or Sales Orders module, the system will use the PO Accrual account (for purchase receipts) or the COGS account (for sales orders). The offset account and subaccount for a receipt, issue, adjustment, or transfer are determined by the document's reason code, which is selected depending on the specific transaction being performed. For different types of inventory transactions, different types of offset accounts should be selected. Reason codes also can be used to gather statistics about specific inventory transactions. You define reason codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form. Each reason code is associated with the type of inventory transaction for which it will be used. For each type of inventory transaction, you can create multiple reason codes, if necessary, to further categorize transactions within their types. By using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form, you can define the reason codes used most frequently with each type of transaction as the default reason code for this type of transactions. For more information on using reason codes, see Reason Codes for Inventory. Posting Classes In Acumatica ERP, you can use posting classes to provide the default accounts and subaccounts for items of the class; in this case, the accounts specified in the posting class are used for assigning the default General Ledger accounts for items. You create posting classes for stock and non-stock items by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, you can assign a posting class to an item class; the system will use this posting class as the default posting class for inventory items of this item class. If needed, you can assign a specific posting class (instead of the default one) to a particular stock item by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, and to a particular non-stock item by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form. For more information on managing item classes, see Item Classes. A posting class defines the rules for selecting General Ledger accounts and subaccounts to be used for transactions with items assigned to the posting class. When a transaction with an inventory item is created, multiple similar accounts are involved. For example, when a stock item is received at a particular warehouse, its cost (a debit amount) can be recorded to either the inventory account associated with the warehouse or the inventory account associated with the inventory item. Subaccounts for various types of transactions can be combined from multiple involved subaccounts, depending on the policies established in your organization. You can select General Ledger accounts and subaccount segment values from the following sources: Inventory item Warehouse Posting class The posting class also provides the account and subaccount to be used if the source of General Ledger accounts for a transaction is a posting class itself. For more details about using posting classes, see Posting Classes in Inventory. Inventory–General Ledger Integration Settings The settings used to configure the integration between the Inventory and General Ledger modules are located on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. The following check boxes are available: Update GL : If this check box is selected, transactions originating in the Inventory module will update the General Ledger module. If this check box is cleared, inventory transactions do not update the General Ledger module, and the inventory can be maintained independently from the General Ledger module. Post Summary on Updating GL : If this check box is selected, the system will include in the batch only summary information (for the account–subaccount pair). If this check box is cleared, the detailed information for each document line will be included in the batch generated for the document. Automatically Post on Release : If this check box is cleared, inventory transactions will not be automatically posted to the General Ledger module on release of nventory documents; the inventory transactions should be posted through the General Ledger module. If this check box is selected, inventory transactions will be posted on the release of inventory documents. Change of an Inventory Account for an Item We recommend that you carefully plan inventory accounts and avoid changing the inventory account for an item after you have started processing transactions with the item. If you change the posting class for an item on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, the General Ledger accounts are repopulated in the item from the new posting class, which may affect the inventory account that is used for transaction processing with the item if the source of the inventory account is set to Inventory Item for the posting class on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form. If you decide to define a specific inventory account for some item-warehouse combinations, we also recommend that you do this during initial configuration. If you need to change the inventory account for an item after you have started processing transactions, the following will happen to inventory transactions after you change the inventory account in an item's settings: Inventory receipts, as well as other transactions that increase inventory, will start to process to the new inventory account retrieved from settings. Inventory issues will continue to clear the old inventory account until its balance is zero. Inventory adjustments will be processed to the new inventory account retrieved from settings. If you want to transfer the item's balance to the new inventory account, we recommend that you do the following: You create a temporary clearing asset account in the General Ledger module. You create an issue reason code for the old inventory account and a receipt reason code for the new inventory account. Keeping the old inventory account in the item settings, you clear the item balance from the old inventory account by doing the following: issue all quantity and cost of the item with the issue reason code that you have defined earlier to clear the balance of the old inventory account, and record the balance to the temporary account. You specify the new inventory account in the settings of the item. You process a receipt with the item quantity you issued earlier (and at the previously specified cost) with the receipt reason code that you have defined earlier. When you do, the balance is recorded back to the new inventory account and the balance of the temporary account is cleared. You make sure the temporary account balance is zero, and deactivate the account on the chart of accounts. After you have performed these steps, the balance is transferred to the new inventory account, and the item is ready for processing additional inventory transactions. Reason Codes for Inventory The majority of transactions with inventory items are performed when the items are purchased or sold, and respective inventory receipts or issues are generated by other documents, such as purchase receipts and sales orders. Because direct inventory transactions (that is, inventory transactions that are not based on any financial documents) are not standard operations, users should specify why the particular inventory transactions were performed. In this topic, you will read about the creation and use of reason codes in the Inventory module. Creation of Reason Codes Before you start configuring the settings of the Inventory module, you must create all necessary reason codes to be used in inventory transactions. You define reason codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form. For each reason code, you must specify the following: Identifier: Identifiers of reason codes may have up to 10 characters and can clearly designate the reason of the transaction, as with DAMAGE , EXPIRATION , SHRINKAGE , and RETURNS . Usage: You specify with what inventory transaction a reason code will be used. You can define reason codes for the following types of inventory transactions: Receipt Issue/return Adjustment Transfer Disassembly General Ledger account: You select the General Ledger account that the system will allocate for transactions with this reason code specified. For details, see General Ledger Accounts for Reason Codes General Ledger Accounts for Reason Codes. General Ledger subaccount and subaccount mask: If you use subaccounts in Acumatica ERP, you specify the subaccount or the subaccount mask (for a combined subaccount) that the system will use for documents with this reason code specified. For details, see Subaccounts for Reason Codes Subaccounts for Reason Codes. Sales account and subaccount: If you create a reason code for issues, you optionally specify a sales account and subaccount for use on sales orders. In addition, the sales account from the reason code can override the sales account in the additional sales transaction that can be generated from an inventory issue. If this Issue reason code is specified in a sales order, it may override the sales and COGS accounts in the transactions that are then generated from the Accounts Receivable invoice and inventory issue. After you have created all required reason codes, you can specify default reason codes on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. For details, see Default Reason Codes for Inventory Transactions Default Reason Codes for Inventory Transactions. General Ledger Accounts for Reason Codes Each reason code provides an offset account to be used for the transaction. The type of the offset account depends on the type of transaction for which the reason code is used with as well as the reason for the transaction; in most cases, the offset account is a kind of expense account to record specific costs. For example, reason codes defined for issues are used to provide offset accounts for specific types of issues. If an issue is created to remove expired goods, the offset account can be Expired Goods' Costs. An inventory return functions similarly to an issue, with the entries reversed. For some sales transactions (which do not refer to any specific sales order type), reason codes may provide a sales account and subaccount because sales subaccounts can be generated only in accordance with the rules specified for the order type on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000]) Order Types (SO201000) form. Subaccounts for Reason Codes For each reason code, if subaccounts are used in your system, you specify a subaccount and a subaccount mask (which can be used for a combined subaccount). By specifying a subaccount mask, you configure a rule that the system uses to compose a new subaccount identifier by using the segment values of multiple subaccounts. In a combined subaccount of a reason code, you can use segments from the following sources: Inventory item ( I ): The subaccount associated with the item Warehouse ( W ): The subaccount associated with the warehouse where the transaction is performed Posting class ( P ): The subaccount associated with the posting class Reason code ( R ): The subaccount associated with the reason code itself For example, suppose that a two-segmented subaccount identifier with three characters in each segment is defined. To combine the subaccount segments of a warehouse and inventory item, you use the following mask: WWW-III , where WWW is the first subaccount segment of a warehouse and III is the second subaccount segment of an inventory item. To use a subaccount associated with a reason code, you type the following mask: RRR-RRR . For details on how to use combined subaccounts, see Combining Subaccounts. Default Reason Codes for Inventory Transactions When an inventory document is created directly in the Inventory module, the reason code defines what account will be used as an offset account and what subaccount will mark the transaction. On release of the transaction, the inventory account (which is copied from the stock item) and the offset account (which is copied from the reason code) will be updated with the amount of the transaction. For each type of inventory transaction, you can specify the default reason code ton the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. You can assign default reason codes for the following inventory transactions: Receipts Issues and returns Adjustment Physical inventory adjustments When you create one of these inventory documents, the system automatically inserts the specified default reason code for the type. Users can replace the default reason code with another reason code defined for the transaction type, if necessary. You specify the default reason code for vendor returns on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO101000|PO101000]) Purchase Orders Preferences (PO101000) form. For more information on processing vendor returns, see Purchase Return Processing. ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) ([~/?ScreenId=SO201000|SO201000])

Posting Classes in Inventory Every inventory transaction creates an appropriate posting to the General Ledger module, depending on the particular inventory item, the type of transaction, the warehouse where the item is stocked, and other conditions. A posting class is a required setting for stock items and defines which accounts and subaccounts should be used to post specific transactions to the General Ledger module. Also, posting classes are used to provide the default General Ledger accounts for stock and non-stock items during the initialization of the system or later, when new stock or non-stock items are being added. In this topic, you will read about posting classes in Acumatica ERP. Creation of Posting Classes When the Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can create posting classes by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form. Before you start creating posting classes, make sure that all necessary General Ledger accounts and subaccounts have been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form. During the creation of a posting class, you specify the following: Class ID: You type a unique identifier that defines the posting class. You can use an alphanumeric string of up to 10 characters as a posting class ID. General Ledger accounts and subaccounts: You specify the General Ledger accounts and subaccounts assigned to the posting class. The exact set of accounts and subaccounts you need to select depends on the items for which you create a posting class. For details, see General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts of a Posting Class General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts of a Posting Class. Posting settings for transactions: You specify which General Ledger account the system must take for which type of transaction, and the rule the system will use to combine subaccounts. For details, see Posting Settings for General Ledger Accounts Posting Settings for General Ledger Accounts and Posting Settings for GL Subaccounts Posting Settings for GL Subaccounts. Reason code for physical inventory: You specify the reason code that the system will use by default for physical inventory involving items associated with this posting class. For details, see Reason Codes for Inventory. For a procedure, see To Create a Posting Class. General Ledger Accounts and Subaccounts of a Posting Class You specify the default General Ledger accounts and subaccounts assigned to a posting class on the GL Accounts tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form. These default General Ledger accounts and subaccounts simplify data entry on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) and ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) forms. When you assign a posting class to an item class or item, the system copies the General Ledger accounts and subaccounts from the posting class to the item class or item settings. In the settings of an item class or item, you can override any of the default accounts and subaccounts, if needed. If you change the posting class for an item class or item, the system updates the General Ledger accounts and subaccounts on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes or ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form with the accounts and subaccounts from the new posting class. For details on General Ledger accounts in inventory, see Posting Settings in the Inventory Module. Posting Settings for General Ledger Accounts General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for inventory transactions related to sales, purchases, and valuation of inventory items can be obtained from multiple sources, depending on the business processes established in your organization. On the Posting Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form, for each type of account, you specify from which source the system will take this account for the posting class. In Acumatica ERP, you can select General Ledger accounts from the following sources: Inventory item : The inventory account for all transactions of the item will be the one specified in the item settings regardless of at what warehouse the inventory transaction occurs. Warehouse : The inventory account will vary depending on the warehouse where the inventory transaction is made. You select this source if you use multiple warehouses in the system and each warehouse has a specific inventory account assigned. Posting class : The inventory account assigned to the posting class itself (as specified on the GL Accounts tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes form) will be used. You select this source when you need to replace the inventory account that was previously used for items of the posting class with a new account. Basic Scenarios of Posting Class Configuration When you create posting classes, you can configure the following basic scenarios: Posting transactions for multiple items to the same General Ledger account: Suppose that you have a single warehouse, and the majority of inventory transactions should be posted to the same General Ledger account. You do the following: You create a posting class and specify for it the inventory account that the system should use for posting inventory transactions. You select Posting Class as the source of the inventory account in the settings of the posting class. You specify the created posting class in the settings of each item class or inventory item. Posting transactions to item-specific General Ledger accounts: Suppose that you have particularly valuable items for which you want to allocate specific General Ledger accounts. You do the following: You specify a separate General Ledger account in the settings of each item class or inventory item that are valuable. You create a posting class; in its settings, you select Inventory Item as the source of the inventory account. You specify the created posting class in the settings of the inventory items that have specific General Ledger accounts. Posting transactions to warehouse-specific General Ledger accounts: Suppose that you have multiple warehouses and you have separate accounts for each warehouse. You do the following: You assign an individual inventory account to each warehouse. You create a posting class and select Warehouse as the source of the inventory account. You assign item classes or items to the created posting class. You can combine basic scenarios to post transactions according to business processes of your organization. Posting Settings for GL Subaccounts If the Subaccounts feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can specify the rules for selecting subaccount segments for inventory transactions that involve items of the posting class. The system can select subaccounts used for transaction posting from the same sources as accounts, but since subaccounts consist of multiple segments, you can combine segment values from different sources to get subaccounts that would reflect all the details of the transaction. For example, if only one inventory account is used in your organization for all inventory items, you might want to provide very specific subaccounts to track which warehouses were involved in every transaction. On the Posting Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form, you can type a subaccount mask that defines how the subaccounts should be composed by using segment values copied from various sources. For each segment, you can select one of the following sources of the segment value: Posting class ( P ) Inventory item ( I ) Warehouse ( W ) Consider a simple example of configuring a subaccount mask for a sales subaccount. Suppose there are four segments in the subaccounts used in the system, which have the XX-XXX-XX-XX format. If you configure the sales subaccount mask as II-III-II-II , it means that for sales transactions, the sales subaccount from the inventory item will be used. If you configure the sales subaccount mask as WW-PPP-II-PP , then for sales transactions, the sales subaccount will be a combination of three subaccounts: The first segment will be copied from the sales subaccount associated with the warehouse. The second and fourth segments will be copied from the sales subaccount associated with the posting class of the item. The third segment will be copied from the sales account associated with the inventory item. For more details on functionality of combined subaccounts, see Combining Subaccounts.
