Units of Measure and Conversions In Acumatica ERP, you can maintain any number of different units of measure (UOMs) to be used to specify the quantities of products that are purchased, stocked, or sold by your company. In addition, you can specify UOMs of weight and volume to calculate freight costs for third-party carriers. Multiple units of measure are required because items can be sold by the piece or be packed into boxes, packages, crates, and other storage units. Some units of measure apply to many products and, as such, are defined globally. Other units of measure are used only for particular products or for groups of similar products. In Acumatica ERP, you can define UOMs and conversion rules at all of these levels, as described in the sections below. Global Units of Measure You use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form to define units of measure that can be used globally for all inventory items. You can add new units of measure to the unit conversion reference table on this form and specify how they are converted to units already defined in the table, if applicable. The global UOMs specified in this table can be used throughout Acumatica ERP and are available for selection when a user selects UOMs for a new item class or a base UOM for an item. You do the following to create an UOM on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure form: In the From Unit and To Unit columns, you type the unique identifier of the UOM (such as KG ). In the Multiply/Divide column, you keep the default value. In the Conversion Factor column, you make sure that the default value, 1.000000 , is specified. After you create all required UOMs, you can create conversion rules (if necessary) so that the system can calculate prices for items in different UOMs correctly. For more information on conversion rules, see Specification of Conversion Rules Specification of Conversion Rules and To Define a Conversion Rule for UOMs. In addition to global UOMs, you can create item-specific UOMs on the fly when you are creating an item class or inventory item. For details, see Default UOMs for Item Classes Default UOMs for Item Classes and Item-Specific UOMs Item-Specific UOMs. UOMs of Weight and Volume If your company uses third-party carriers to deliver sold goods to customers or purchases from vendors, you may need to define UOMs of weight and volume to calculate specific freight amounts. After you have created all required UOMs and conversion rules on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form, you can specify global UOMs for weight and volume on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies (CS101500) form. The system will use these UOMs to calculate freight costs. You can specify weight and volume UOMs for each stock and non-stock item on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) and ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) forms, respectively. UOMs specified on these forms have a higher priority than global UOMs specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies form. For information on UOMs used to measure the weight and volume of the items listed on sales orders and purchase receipts, see Units of Weight and Volume. Default UOMs for Item Classes If the Multiple Units of Measure feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, for each item class that is defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, you can specify the following units to be used by default for items of the class: Base Unit : The unit of measure used to calculate unit costs for items of the class. For stock items, this unit is used for maintaining availability data. Users count the quantities of each stock item at warehouses by using the UOM specified as the base unit for the item. For recommendations on selecting base units, see Base Unit Selection Base Unit Selection. Sales Unit : The unit of measure typically used when your company sells the item. Purchase Unit : The unit of measure typically used when your company purchases the item. If the Multiple Units of Measure feature is not enabled in your system, you can specify only base units for item classes as well as for individual stock and non-stock items. If you decide later to enable the Multiple Units of Measure feature, the sales and purchase units for each item class (as well as for each stock and non-stock item) will be assigned the values from the appropriate base units. You can select globally defined units of measure or type a class-specific UOM. Once you have typed a new UOM, a new line with this UOM is added to the conversion tables automatically, so that you can specify how this UOM is converted to the base unit of the class. For detailed instructions, see To Create an UOM. The system will not automatically add class-specific units to the global unit conversion reference table on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure form. The base, sales, and purchase UOMs selected for the class will provide the default values of these settings for items of this class. Item-Specific UOMs For particular items of the class, on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) or ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, you can select the base, sales, and purchase units. (Boxes for sales and purchase UOMs are displayed only if the Multiple Units of Measure feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form.) By default, the system assigns the base, sales, and purchase units of the class to the item. If you need to specify other UOMs, you can select UOMs from the list of globally defined UOMs or type new units. The system will automatically add the new item-specific UOMs to the table of units conversion on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form— that is, to the list of globally defined UOMs. If you need to change the item's base UOM (or the sales or purchase UOM, if applicable), make sure that the rules for conversion between the current and new UOMs are specified before you use the item with any new UOM in any new transaction. When you enter a transaction and specify the quantity of the inventory item and its unit of measure, the system converts the specified UOM to the base unit for cost-of-sold-goods calculation and to the default sales unit for finding the proper price (or the item's other unit for which the price can be found). Cross-Reference Units of Measure Stock or non-stock items may have alternate IDs specified on the Cross-References tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) or ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form. You can assign these items UOMs other than the default sales and purchase units of measure to be used when users enter documents with lines in which they enter these alternate IDs. For detailed information, see Using Cross-Reference Units of Measure in Item Cross-References. Base Unit Selection You may want to select for each item a base unit that is the smallest unit you would ever use when buying or selling the product, so you can avoid any problems caused by rounding. To understand this guideline, consider an example: Suppose that you purchase and stock a product (canned juice) in boxes of 12 cans, and you select a box as the base unit for this product. If you then decided to sell the product by cans, you would need to specify quantities in fractions or define the sales unit (if sales and purchase units are enabled in your system) as 0.0833333 (one-twelfth) of the base unit. Further imagine that one customer wants to buy 5 cans and another wants to buy another 5 cans. In both cases, the sales order would specify 0.417 units (5 * 0.0833333), and each customer would get 5 cans. However, the remaining 0.166 units don't actually equate to the 2 cans left in the box. During a financial period, in a warehouse, these rounding problems could cause a significant discrepancy between the quantities on books and the physical quantities. During physical inventory, counting is performed in base units, so if the base unit for the product is not the smallest UOM applicable to the item, counting results may prove incorrect. Considering the above example, counting only boxes can result in incorrect total number of cans because some of the boxes may not be full. Thus, we recommend using a base unit that is the smallest unit your company uses when buying and selling the product. Specification of Conversion Rules When you define conversion rules for UOMs, make sure that the decimal precision specified in the Quantity Decimal Places box on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies (CS101500) form does not cut off any meaningful digits. If different UOMs are used as base, sales, and purchase units, you specify conversion rules with respect to the UOM selected as the base unit for the item. For instance, suppose an item is sold to customers by the piece ( PIECE ), making PIECE its sales unit. The product is stocked in boxes, and each box ( BOX ) includes 16 pieces. The product is purchased from a vendor in containers. Each container ( CONTAINER ) contains 20 boxes, and the purchase unit is CONTAINER . As the base unit, you can select PIECE or BOX . (The smallest unit is usually selected, for reasons described in the previous section.) If you selected PIECE , you would specify the following conversion rules. From Unit Multiply/Divide Conversion Factor To Unit CONTAINER Multiply 320 PIECE BOX Multiply 16 PIECE Notice that the specified conversion rules are not reversible—the system cannot use the rule in the first row of the above table to recalculate the quantity specified in pieces to the quantity specified in containers. Also, any conversion should be specified directly with respect to the base UOM, and it would be impossible to convert any quantity specified in containers to the quantity specified in boxes if you specify the rules as follows. From Unit Multiply/Divide Conversion Factor To Unit CONTAINER Multiply 20 BOX BOX Multiply 16 PIECE If you decide to use BOX as the base unit, you must define the rules differently, as follows. From Unit Multiply/Divide Conversion Factor To Unit CONTAINER Multiply 20 BOX PIECE Divide 16 BOX ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100])

Units of Weight and Volume When a carrier is used to deliver products from your organization to a customer, the carrier can charge your company specific freight amounts that depend on the weights or volumes of the packages in shipments. The carrier may also set restrictions on the weight or volume of packages. Landed costs incurred for shipments delivered from vendors to your company can be calculated by the weight or volume of the items in the shipment. In Acumatica ERP, you can select the base units of measure (UOMs) for weight and volume and set up the automatic calculation of weights and volumes for sales and purchase orders. In this topic, you will read about weight and volume UOMs. The Base Weight and Volume UOMs You use the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies (CS101500) form to specify the base UOMs for weight and volume. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form, you should first create a unit of measure (UOM) to be used in your system as the base UOM for weight. The weights of all sales and purchase orders will be calculated in this UOM. However, if the items differ in weight significantly, you can create other UOMs for measuring the weights of the base units of stock and non-stock items. For each additional weight UOM, you must specify the rules for converting this UOM to the base weight UOM. For example, suppose that you need to create weight UOMs for a gram ( GRAM ) and pound ( LB ) and define conversion rules to convert the weights measured in pounds to weights measured in grams and to convert the weights measured in grams to weights measured in pounds. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure form, you would do the following: Create the GRAM UOM for grams. Create the LB UOM for pounds. Create a conversion rule from grams to pounds with the Multiply conversion type and 453.5923 conversion factor Create a conversion rules from pounds to grams with the Multiply conversion type and 0.0022046 conversion factor Here you specify the conversion factor as 0.0022046 with 7 decimal places. This value shows how many pounds one gram contains. In your system, the decimal precision is defined in the Quantity Decimal Places box on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS101500|CS101500]) Companies (CS101500) form. Make sure that the selected decimal precision does not cut off any meaningful digits. For instance, if you set the number of decimal places for quantities to 2, this would result in incorrect conversions from grams to pounds. For a general procedure that describes how to create UOMs and conversion rules, see To Create an UOM. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure form, you should define a UOM that will be used in your system to measure the volume of specific quantities of the items listed on sales and purchase orders. You should also define all other UOMs that may be used to measure the volumes that the base units of various items can take and specify the conversion factors with respect to the base volume UOM. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form, select the base weight UOM in the Weight UOM box and select the base volume UOM in the Volume UOM box. Weight and Volume of Stock Items For each stock item, you can specify the weight and the volume (measured in a specific volume UOM) of its base unit on the Packaging tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. For non-stock items, you can specify these values (if applicable) by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form. For the item-specific weight and volume UOMs, you must specify rules for conversion to the appropriate base UOMs either on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form or on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form. If the Multiple Units of Measure feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS101000) form, make sure that rules for converting each sales and purchase unit to the base UOM selected for the item are defined in the system. Also, if the Use a Price Adjustment Multiplier check box is selected on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) form, you can specify a price adjustment multiplier for the item. For more information on adjusting prices, see Units of Measure and Conversions. Weight and Volume Calculation for Purchase Receipts The system can calculate the weight and volume of the received quantities of stock and non-stock items for each purchase receipt. The landed cost specified for each purchase receipt can be split among the items listed in the receipt in proportion to the item weights or volumes (among other options). For more information, see Processing Landed Cost Documents. ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100])

Inventory Items Many businesses consider inventory to be an important asset. Inventory includes stock items : the finished goods and raw materials that cost money, have value, and are stored. Along with stock items, businesses may sell non-stock items : usually non-physical goods, such as services and warranties, that are not stocked. Stock and non-stock items, which are processed differently in Acumatica ERP, are both referred to as inventory items . For each inventory item, you create a record in the database that provides information about the type of the item, its identifier, its description, the General Ledger accounts allocated for the item, its price and cost information, the various units of measure (UOMs) that apply to it, and the conversions between UOMs. The records for stock items contain additional information required to track the items in the system. This topic highlights general information about inventory items, the major differences between stock and non-stock items, and the processing of inventory items in Acumatica ERP. Inventory IDs Each inventory item is tracked in the system by its inventory ID. This unique identifier can be just a number, or you can configure it to provide basic information about the item type, brand, or use. Inventory IDs can be designed to help you sort and group items for reports. As with other identifiers in Acumatica ERP, inventory IDs can be configured on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS202000|CS202000]) Segmented Keys (CS202000) form. Identifiers for stock and non-stock items are configured by using the same segmented key: INVENTORY . For the key, you can define how many segments it will have, what values may be used, whether they should be validated, and whether auto-numbering should be used for generating inventory IDs. To have inventory IDs automatically generated on creating new inventory items, you can configure the INVENTORY segmented key as having a single segment with the Auto-Number option selected for this segment and a numbering sequence specified in the Numbering ID box. If users will enter inventory IDs manually, you can configure the INVENTORY key as having a single segment with non-validated values. If the type of items should be indicated by their IDs, consider configuring the INVENTORY key with two segments and creating a list of predefined values for one of the segments. For details on segmented keys, see Segmented Identifiers. When configuring the INVENTORY segmented key, decide whether you will use alternate IDs for stock and non-stock items. If you enter alternate IDs (item identifiers used by the vendors and customer of the items), users will be able to specify items by typing their alternate IDs as well as inventory IDs in the Inventory ID boxes on sales and purchase orders without the system generating errors. For more information on using alternate IDs and on how to configure the INVENTORY segmented key in this case, see Item Cross-References. If required, you can change the inventory ID for any non-stock or stock item manually by clicking Actions Change ID on the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) or ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, respectively, and by specifying the new inventory ID in the dialog box that opens. Your company might want to use subitems to further categorize otherwise-identical stock items with properties such as colors or sizes that are important to customers. Thus, under the same inventory ID, you may have a number of subitems—products that share all the settings of the inventory item's record but have additional properties that differ. If your company has decided to use subitems, all stock items will be identified by a combination of inventory ID and subitem code. For more details, see Inventory Subitems. Stock Items If the Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can create stock items on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Stock items are usually physical goods that you purchase or manufacture and sell to your customers. Examples of stock items include computers, cell phones, cables, and auto parts. Stock items may have lot or serial numbers that you can use to track the items in your system. You can create a stock item of any of the following types: Finished Good , Component Part , or Subassembly . The type of a stock item is intended for informational purposes and does not affect processing. The system automatically tracks stock items and maintains availability data. You can track stock items by their cost value. For more information on stock items, see Stock Items. Non-Stock Items Non-stock items are typically non-physical goods (such as labor, services, or warranties), or items with very low values that might be hard to track. Examples might include labor and repair charges, warranties, and small repair or installation parts. You enter each non-stock item on the (IN202000) form and specify one of the following types: Non-Stock Item , Labor , Service , Charge , or Expense . Available quantities of non-stock items are not tracked by the system; they are treated as if they are available in any quantity at any time. A line on a sales order that features a non-stock item cannot be back ordered. For more information on non-stock items, see Non-Stock Items in the Inventory Module. Posting Classes for Item Classes and Inventory Items Posting classes facilitate specifying General Ledger accounts for multiple new inventory items assigned to specific item classes. Each item class has a posting class assigned. When a user creates a new stock item by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, the item is assigned to an item class and, hence, to a specific posting class. If necessary, the user can select another posting class for the item. Once the posting class is selected, the General Ledger accounts and subaccounts for the item on the GL Accounts tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form will be filled in based on the accounts and subaccounts specified on the GL Accounts tab of the posting class (the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes form). When you create new non-stock items by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, posting classes are also used to provide the default accounts and subaccounts for these items. For more information about posting classes, see Posting Classes in Inventory. ([~/?ScreenId=CS202000|CS202000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500])

Item Classes In Acumatica ERP, you can create item classes on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form to group stock or non-stock items with similar properties and to provide default settings for new items. Users specify an item class when they create a new stock or non-stock item on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) or ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, and the system fills in many values, thus saving users time and increasing the accuracy of the entered data. Some of these default values can be overridden for individual items, if needed. The item class is a required setting for a stock item. For details about how to create an item class, see To Create an Item Class. In this topic, you will read about item classes in Acumatica ERP. Item Class Settings Each item class can specify the following: Whether the class groups stock items, for which the system generates inventory transactions, or non-stock items, which is not tracked in inventory. The default settings that the item class provides to items of the class and that you can change later by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items or ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items form. For details, see Default Settings for Inventory Items Default Settings for Inventory Items. The availability calculation rule that applies to the items of the item class that groups stock items. For details, see Availability Calculation Rules in an Item Class Availability Calculation Rules in an Item Class. The hierarchy of item classes. For details, see Hierarchy of Item Classes Hierarchy of Item Classes. The method of demand calculation for replenishment of items that are grouped by the item class. For more information, see Automated Replenishment. The configuration of custom attributes that items might have, such as color and size. For details, see Inventory Item Attributes. You can specify default item classes in the Default Stock Item Class and Default Non-Stock Item Class boxes on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. The system will copy the settings of the default item class to newly created stock and non-stock item classes. Default Settings for Inventory Items The default settings that an item class provides to inventory items are the following: Item type (these types are different for stock and non-stock items) Valuation method Tax category Posting class Lot or serial number Default warehouse Units of measure Custom attributes Replenishment class You can plan item classes so that they aggregate as much information as possible about the groups of similar inventory items, including the posting classes. After you configure the item classes in this way, you will have to specify a minimum of information for individual inventory items during manual data entry or import—for example, only Inventory ID , Description , and Item Class —while the rest of the information will be automatically populated based on the selected item class. Availability Calculation Rules in an Item Class The system tracks the on-hand quantity of items in inventory and calculates the available quantity of items, which can be used for inventory planning and replenishment. You might want to include anticipated goods in the available quantity, which you can specify in the availability calculation settings. The availability calculation rule is defined at the item class level and cannot be changed for particular items. For more information, see Availability Calculation. Hierarchy of Item Classes You can configure the INITEMCLASS segmented key so that it has multiple segments, each denoting a level of item class hierarchy. Then you can define the hierarchy of item classes and use item classes for categorizing items. To use item classes for categorizing items, you can set the hierarchy of the item classes directly in the item class IDs. For example, suppose that your organization sells electronics and computers. You can create an item class for computers and include child item classes for laptops, monitors, and keyboards in this item class. Similarly, you can create an item class for electronics with item classes for audio players, speakers, and headphones included. For details on hierarchical item classes, see Hierarchy of Item Classes . ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500])

Stock Items In Acumatica ERP, stock items are usually physical goods (such as computers, cell phones, cables, and auto parts) that you purchase or manufacture and sell to your customers. Stock items may have lot or serial numbers you can use to track the items in your system. You can create stock items by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form only if the Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. In this topic, you can find information about stock items in Acumatica ERP. Configuration of Stock Items You use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form to create stock items in the system. You must create a stock item for each good that you purchase or sell and that you want to track in the Inventory module. To create a stock item, you do the following: You type a unique inventory ID for the item. For more information, see Inventory IDs in Inventory Items. You select one of the existing item classes, which will provide default settings to the item, such as item type, valuation method, tax category, posting class, default warehouse, availability calculation rules, units of measure and replenishment settings. For details, see Item Classes. Optional: You change any of the settings provided by the selected item class as needed. Optional: If you use multiple warehouse locations, you select locations for issue and receipt for the stock item you are configuring. For more information on warehouse locations, see Warehouse Locations. Optional: If you use third-party carriers to deliver the stock item, you specify the weight or volume of the item and select a packaging option. For details, see Automatic Packaging for Integrated Carriers. For details about how to create a stock item, see To Create a Stock Item. Types of Stock Items You select one of the following stock item types, which are used for informational purposes only and designate the inventories that a company may have, for each stock item: Finished Good : You use this type for finished goods that you sell to customers. Component Part : You can use this type for component items from which intermediate assemblies and finished goods are produced during kit assembly processes. Subassembly : You can use this type for intermediate assemblies from which finished goods are produced during kit assembly processes. Transactions with Stock Items After you have created stock items in the system and configured their settings, you can start processing transactions. Unlike with non-stock items, transactions with stock items need to be processed starting from the forms of the Purchase Orders or Sales Orders module, such as ([~/?ScreenId=SO301000|SO301000]) Sales Orders (SO301000) or ([~/?ScreenId=PO301000|PO301000]) Purchase Orders (PO301000) form. From these modules, the system generates the proper inventory transactions and the corresponding Accounts Payable and Accounts Receivable documents. Stock items cannot be manually selected in Accounts Receivable invoices. In Accounts Payable bills, you can select stock items; however, the Accounts Payable documents can be released only after all lines with stock items are linked to the corresponding lines of the purchase receipts that have been released in the Purchase Orders module. You cannot delete a stock item in the system if there are any completed transactions with the item, any unreleased documents that includes this item, or any nonzero quantity of the item at any warehouse location. Stock Item Tracking The system automatically tracks stock items and maintains availability data: how many base units are on hand, how many are ordered from vendors, and how many are booked to sales orders and shipments. You can configure how exactly the availability data is computed, and the data is updated as the item is received, invoiced, adjusted, or transferred. For details, see Availability Calculation. Stock items are also tracked by their cost value. Various valuation methods are available for tracking item costs (for details, see Item Costs and Valuation Methods). Typically, a stock item is an asset until it is sold. Its cost becomes an expense. The system also automatically monitors when the stock level of the item falls below the defined minimum and automatically calculates the quantities required to replenish the stock, based on the demand for the item and the inventory information you have defined for the stock item. For details, see Automated Replenishment. ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000])

Non-Stock Items in the Inventory Module Non-stock items, which are defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, may be "products" that are not physical entities and thus cannot be stocked in warehouses. Many organizations sell items that can’t be found on their shelves, such as product warranties, or services such as product assembly, installation, or customization. Whereas some items are obviously non-stock, such as labor rates and services, other items that are physical entities (such as gift-wrapping) can be either stock or non-stock. The decision about whether to consider physical entities stock or non-stock depends on the company's inventory policies and other conditions. In the system, non-stock items are handled differently from stock items that are kept in warehouses (and tracked accordingly). For stock items, the system maintains all cost, quantity, sales, and cost-of-goods-sold information. Because non-stock items do not require the tracking of quantities, the system maintains only standard costs and base price information for them. If the Inventory and Order Management group of features is not included in your Acumatica ERP license, you will be able to create non-stock items and use them in the Accounts Receivable and Accounts Payable documents. However, you will not be able to define posting classes for them or to update their prices and costs in bulk. If the Inventory and Order Management group of features is enabled but the Inventory feature is not enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can still use non-stock items in sales orders, purchase orders, and purchase requisitions with some limitations. (Some elements you use for non-stock items, such as the Require Receipt and Require Shipment boxes, are unavailable. For more information about settings that depend on this feature, see the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form reference.) Types of Non-Stock Items Acumatica ERP supports the following types of non-stock items, one of which can be selected in the Type box of the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form: Non-Stock Item : A general type of a non-stock item. You can use it for any unspecific type of non-physical items or for physical items that you don't need to register in inventory. Labor or Labor Item : A non-stock item mostly used as a source of General Ledger accounts for recording sales of labor. Service : A non-stock item to designate service fees. Charge : A non-stock item that represents charges of a specific type. Expense : A non-stock item that represents expenses of a specific type. On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, you can create item classes for non-stock items to provide default settings for each type of non-stock item used in your business. With these classes defined, users can specify an item class when they use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items form to define a new non-stock item, and the system fills in common values, thus saving time and increasing accuracy. Settings for Non-Stock Items Information about non-stock items and their properties is maintained on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form, which is available in the Accounts Receivable, Accounts Payable, and Inventory modules. The list below describes some of the settings you can provide for a non-stock item by using this form: Inventory ID: Every non-stock item is assigned an unique identifier based on the INVENTORY segmented key. For details on the ways the identifier can be configured, see Inventory Items. For material non-stock items, you can specify a default warehouse and specify whether the items require shipping and receipts on purchase. If subitems are used in your system, they do not apply to non-stock items. Units of measure and conversion rules: For each non-stock item, you can select the units of measure (UOMs) used as base, sales, and purchase units for the item and specify conversion rules for them and for other UOMs used for the item. You can select UOMs from the list of those available for the item class or enter new UOMs on the fly. Every conversion rule is specified with respect to the UOM selected as the item's base unit. Packaging options: If the non-stock item requires shipping, specify the weight of the base unit and the UOM used to measure the weight. General Ledger accounts and subaccounts (if subaccounts are applicable in your system): Purchases and sales of non-stock items do not affect companies' assets, so the General Ledger accounts and subaccounts used for non-stock items are limited to sales accounts, expense accounts, and accounts required for posting transactions related to kit assembly if the item is a kit or a kit component. You can use subaccounts to detail records within each account. If a receipt is required for a non-stock item, a price variance account and a purchase accrual account must be specified to record purchases of this non-stock item. When the receipt is matched to the invoice, any price variance for the non-stock item is recorded to the specified price variance account. Posting class: If the Inventory feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can create posting classes to provide default sales or expense accounts and subaccounts for non-stock items. If no posting class is specified for a non-stock item, the default expense subaccount is generated according to the rule specified in the Combine Expense Sub. From box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AP101000|AP101000]) Accounts Payable Preferences (AP101000) form and the default sales subaccount is specified in the Combine Sales Sub. From box on the ([~/?ScreenId=AR101000|AR101000]) Accounts Receivable Preferences (AR101000) form. Price information: For non-stock items of all types, you can specify price classes and assign prices that become effective on specific dates. Only the standard cost valuation method applies to non-stock items. Non-Stock Item Costs Non-stock items do not affect the company's inventory balance. However, to make it possible to enter the non-stock item cost and use it in the non-stock item price calculation, you can maintain standard costs for non-stock items. The standard costs are determined outside of the system, and the values should include some of the indirect and direct costs allocated. You can specify the standard cost for a non-stock item as a pending cost on the Price/Cost Information tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form. Along with the pending cost, you can specify a date when the cost will become effective. Standard costs are defined with respect to the base unit of the stock item. If you want to update standard costs for non-stock items, use the Price/Cost Information tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items form. You enter a pending cost and the date for the new cost and then click Actions > Update Cost on the form toolbar. The system displays only the last cost and the current cost. The historical costs that were effective before the last cost are not stored in the database. If you want to make similar changes to many or all non-stock (and possibly stock) items, use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN502000|IN502000]) Update Standard Costs (IN502000) form. On this form, you can enter new costs and compare current and pending costs side by side for all items that you select. If you are satisfied with the changes, you can update the current standard costs with the pending standard costs for all items or only selected ones. For details, see Item Costs and Valuation Methods. Prices for Non-Stock Items You can enter default prices for non-stock items individually by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form and update the prices any time. Default prices have no expiration dates and cannot be specified as based on the items' quantities. For more information, see Default Prices. ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN502000|IN502000])

Inventory Item Security An organization that distributes goods may have many items in stock. In this case, users who work with inventory items in the system may have specific tasks and work with only particular item classes. When users create a sales order, they need to enter an inventory ID for each product. You can define restriction groups to limit the lists of inventory items particular users see. In this topic, you will read about managing the visibility of inventory items to users in the system. In Acumatica ERP, you can configure groups with direct and inverse restriction. In this topic, for simplicity, groups with direct restriction are used in examples. You can use inverse restriction groups in the same way as you use direct restriction groups. For details on the types of restriction groups, see Types of Restriction Groups. Visibility of Inventory Items to Users The list of inventory items from which employees should select an item can be very long, which increases the probability of an entry error. By using restriction groups, you can reduce the list of inventory items that users see on forms. For more information about restriction groups, see Restriction Groups in Acumatica ERP. For example, suppose that your organization sells furniture, and that each sales manager works with furniture for a particular room, such as kitchen, living room, and bedroom. When managers create a sales order, they should select items from only the list of furniture they sell to avoid entry mistakes. Further suppose that User K sells kitchen furniture, User L sells living room furniture, and User M sells bedroom furniture. To restrict the visibility of inventory items to the appropriate users in the system, you would create the following restriction groups with direct restriction on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN103000|IN103000]) Inventory Item Access (IN103000) form: Group K: In this group, include User K and all inventory IDs for kitchen furniture items. Group L: To this group, add User L and all inventory IDs for items of living room furniture. Group M: In this group, include User M and all inventory IDs for bedroom furniture items. As a result, the visibility of the inventory items in sales orders will be restricted in the system as follows: User K can view and select only inventory items for kitchen furniture. User L can work with only inventory items for living room furniture. User M can see and select only inventory items for bedroom furniture. Other users cannot see the inventory items that have been added to the three restriction groups in the system. Forms for Inventory Item Security In the following table, you can find the list of the forms that you can use to manage restriction groups with inventory items and the tasks that you can perform by using each form. Task Form To initially configure the visibility of an inventory item to users ([~/?ScreenId=IN103000|IN103000]) Inventory Item Access (IN103000) To change the visibility of an inventory item in multiple restriction groups ([~/?ScreenId=IN103020|IN103020]) Restriction Groups by Item (IN103020) To change the visibility of inventory items to a user in multiple restriction groups ([~/?ScreenId=SM201035|SM201035]) Restriction Groups by User (SM201035) For information about how to add or remove objects from a restriction group, see Operations with Restriction Groups. ([~/?ScreenId=IN103000|IN103000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN103020|IN103020]) ([~/?ScreenId=SM201035|SM201035])

To Specify Basic Inventory Preferences Before configuring any other settings in the Inventory module, you must specify the basic settings of the module by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form, as described in this topic. All of the settings mentioned in the topic are available when the Inventory feature is enabled under the Standard Inventory group of features and the Advanced Inventory feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Before you start configuring the Inventory module, make sure that the following is done in the system: On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, the Inventory feature (under the Standard Inventory group of features) are enabled. By enabling these features, you activate the basic functionality of the following modules: Inventory Purchase Orders Sales Orders The basic functionality provides one default warehouse, and gives you the ability to configure purchase order processing for regular orders and configure sales order processing with the predefined order types. On the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form, all the General Ledger accounts that you will use for inventory have been added. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form, all reason codes that you will use for inventory have been added. On the ([~/?ScreenId=CS201010|CS201010]) Numbering Sequences (CS201010) form, all numbering sequences that you plan to use for batches, receipts, issues, adjustments, and physical inventory documents have been added or modified. To Specify Basic Inventory Preferences Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Numbering Settings section of the General Settings tab, make sure that the needed numbering sequence for each transaction type is selected. In the AR Clearing Account box of the Account Settings section, select the General Ledger account to be used as the Accounts Receivable clearing account for inventory issues (of the Invoice , Debit Memo , and Credit Memo types) that originate in the Inventory module and are not yet associated with any customer. Optional: In the Posting Settings section, specify the following: Select the Update GL check box if you want the system to start generating General Ledger transactions when users release inventory entries. Select the Post Summary on Updating GL check box if you want the system to post batches with summary data (totaled for each account and subaccount pair) to the General Ledger. Select the Automatically Post on Release check box if you want the system to release and immediately post the batch of journal transactions that has been generated on release of an inventory documents. In the Default Reason Codes section of the General Settings tab, specify the default reason codes to be used for receipts, issues, adjustments, and physical inventory documents. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

Before you start creating inventory items in the system, you need to define posting settings by creating posting classes. You use the [HelpRoot_FormReference\IN_20_60_00|Posting Classes] ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) form to create posting classes in the system. In this topic, you will find information about creating a posting class with basic settings—that is, the ''Inventory'' feature is enabled under the ''Standard Inventory'' group of features and the ''Advanced Inventory'' feature is disabled on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_10_00_00|Enable/Disable Features] ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) form.[anchor|#_c07ee94a-d98a-4fc7-89e0-110caa0f5586]((({S:Hint}To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see [HelpRoot_Interface\UIG__con_New_UI_Search|Search in the Modern UI]. ))) ==Before You Proceed==[anchor|#_6bfc656e-a41c-4ab5-a51c-4c93346825f7] *Make sure that all General Ledger accounts and subaccounts that you will use in a posting class have been created on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\GL_20_25_00|Chart of Accounts] ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) form. *Make sure that all reason codes that you will use in this posting class have been created on the [HelpRoot_FormReference\CS_21_10_00|Reason Codes] ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) form.

To Create a Posting Class Before you start creating inventory items in the system, you need to define posting settings by creating posting classes. You use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form to create posting classes in the system. In this topic, you will find information about creating a posting class with basic settings—that is, the Inventory feature is enabled under the Standard Inventory group of features and the Advanced Inventory feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Make sure that all General Ledger accounts and subaccounts that you will use in a posting class have been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=GL202500|GL202500]) Chart of Accounts (GL202500) form. Make sure that all reason codes that you will use in this posting class have been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS211000|CS211000]) Reason Codes (CS211000) form. To Create a Posting Class Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Class ID box, type the unique identifier to be used for the posting class. Optional: In the Description box, type a description of the posting class that will help users to identify it. On the Posting Settings tab, do the following: Specify the sources of General Ledger accounts as follows: If you want the system to use the accounts specified in the posting class for inventory items, in the required Use ... Account From boxes, select Posting Class . If you are specifying item-specific accounts in the settings of each inventory item, in the required Use ... Account From boxes, select Inventory Item . Optional: In the Phys. Inventory Reason Code box, specify the reason code that the system will use for physical inventory. On the GL Accounts tab, specify the accounts that are required for inventory transactions according to the business processes of your organization. On the form toolbar, click Save to save the posting class.

row.PlainText: To Create an UOM You can define new units of measure (UOMs) by using the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form, as described in this topic. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. To Create an UOM Open the ([~/?ScreenId=CS203100|CS203100]) Units of Measure (CS203100) form by searching for or navigating to it. On the toolbar, click Add Row to append a new line to the table. In the From Unit column, type a name for the new unit. In the To Unit column, type the name of the new UOM that you specified in the From Unit column. In the Multiply/Divide column, select the appropriate function. In the Conversion Factor column, type the conversion coefficient. On the toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

To Create an Item Class You use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form to create item classes. In this topic, you will find information about creating an item class with basic settings—that is, the Inventory feature is enabled under the Standard Inventory group of features and the Advanced Inventory feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form—for stock items and for non-stock items. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. To Create an Item Class for Stock Items Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Class ID box, type the unique identifier to be used for the item class. Optional: In the Description box, type a description of the item class that will help users to identify it. In the General Settings section of the General Settings tab, specify the following: Select the Stock Item check box to indicate that the item class is intended for stock items. In the Tax Category box, select the tax category that the system will apply to all items of this class. In the Posting Class box, select the posting class that will determine the posting settings for items of this class. In the Availability Calculation Rule box, select the availability calculation rule to be used for calculating the availability of stock items of this item class. In the Base Unit box of the Unit of Measure section, specify the unit of measure (UOM) to be used as the base unit for items of this class. You can select a globally defined UOM or type a new UOM on the fly. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. Optional: Specify this item class as the default item class for stock item classes as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Default Stock Item Class box of the Data Entry Settings section, select the created item class from the list. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Create an Item Class for Non-Stock Items Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Class ID box, type the unique identifier to be used for the item class. Optional: In the Description box, type a description of the item class that will help users to identify it. In the General Settings section of the General Settings tab, specify the following: Clear the Stock Item check box to indicate that the item class is intended for non-stock items. In the Tax Category box, select the tax category to be applied to all items of this class. In the Posting Class box, select the posting class that will determine the posting settings for items of this class. In the Base Unit box of the Unit of Measure section, specify the unit of measure (UOM) to be used as the base unit for items of this class. You can select a globally defined UOM or type a new UOM on the fly. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. Optional: Specify this item class as the default item class for non-stock item classes as follows: Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Default Non-Stock Item Class box of the Data Entry Settings section, select the created item class from the list. On the form toolbar, click Save . If you have more features under the Inventory and Order Management group of features enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you may want to specify other settings for the item class.

To Create a Stock Item You use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form to create stock items you want to track. In this topic, you will read how to create a stock item with basic settings—that is, the Inventory feature is enabled under the Standard Inventory group of features and the Advanced Inventory feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Make sure that you have created an item class for stock items that will provide default settings for the item. To Create a Stock Item Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Inventory ID box, specify the unique identifier for the stock item. Optional: In the Description box, type a description of the stock item that will help users identify it. On the General Settings tab, in the Item Class box, select the item class that will provide default settings for the stock item. Make sure that the default settings copied from the item class are applicable to the stock item. If not, specify new values for settings, as needed. Optional: On the Price/Cost Info tab, specify the settings to calculate the cost and price for the stock item. Optional: On the Vendor Details tab, add vendors that supply the stock item to you. Optional: On the Packaging tab, specify the weight and volume dimensions for the stock item to be used by third-party carriers. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

To Create a Non-Stock Item for Inventory You use the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form to create non-stock items you want to track in the system. This topic describes how to create a non-stock item for inventory with basic settings—that is, when the Inventory feature is enabled under the Standard Inventory group of features and the Advanced Inventory feature is disabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Optional: If you use item classes for non-stock items, make sure that you have created an item class that provides default settings for the item you are creating. If you do not use item classes, make sure that the posting class, the tax category, and the units of measure that you want to use for the item have been created in the system. To Create a Non-Stock Item for Inventory Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Inventory ID box, type the unique identifier of the item. In the Description box, type a description of the item that will help users identify it. Optional: In the Item Class box of the Item Defaults section on the General Settings tab, select the item class to be used to provide default settings. Make sure that the default settings copied from the item class are applicable to the non-stock item. If not, specify new values for settings, as needed. If you have not specified an item class, on the General Settings tab, do the following : In the Posting Class box of the Item Defaults section, specify the posting class to provide posting settings for the item. In the Tax Category box, specify the tax category to be applied to the item. In the Base Unit box of the Unit of Measure section, specify the base unit of measure for the item. Optional: On the Price/Cost Information tab, specify the settings to calculate cost and price for the non-stock item. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes.

row.PlainText: Managing Inventory Kits If your organization sells not only individual inventory items but also bundles of stock or non-stock items to its customers, you can treat these bundles as single items referred to as inventory kits in Acumatica ERP. In this chapter, you will find information about kit types and the configuration and management of kits. In This Chapter Inventory Item KitsStock KitsNon-Stock KitsTo Create a Stock KitTo Create a Specification for a Stock KitTo Add a Revision to a Stock KitTo Assemble a Stock KitTo Disassemble a Stock KitTo Create a Non-Stock KitTo Create a Specification for a Non-Stock Kit

row.column: Inventory Item Kits A kit is a bundle of stock and non-stock items that increases the value of the kit components. In Acumatica ERP, you can use kits of inventory items if your organization sells multiple inventory items together and wants to track these items as a whole. For example, suppose that an organization sells cheese and wine and also offers nicely packed baskets with a bottle of wine and a set of cheese that pairs well with this wine. To track these baskets in the Inventory module, the organization uses kits, which include a bottle of wine, several cheeses, and a basket as stock items, and the delivery service and packaging as non-stock items. To use the kit functionality, make sure the Kit Assembly feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. In this topic, you will read about kit types and revisions of kit specifications. Kit Types You can create stock and non-stock kits. The main difference between these kit types is that the system tracks stock kits in inventory and does not track non-stock kits. The table below compares stock and non-stock kits. Stock Kit Non-Stock Kit Components Stock components Yes Yes Non-stock components Yes Yes Kit specification revisions Multiple One Issue of components of s stock kit When a kit is assembled When a kit is issued Expense accrual for non-stock components When a kit is assembled Not applicable Lot- or serial-numbered components Serial-numbered components can be used only in serial-numbered kits Yes, except for components with the When-Used assignment method or the User-Enterable issue method Kit units (single entities of a kit) Production/disassembly transactions Required Not applicable Inventory tracking Yes, as a regular stock item; stock components do not exist in inventory after the kit is assembled No; stock components are tracked individually Inventory value Value of the kit unit received to inventory upon production Values of its stock components Availability tracking Yes No Receipt of a kit unit On kit production transaction Not applicable Issue of a kit unit Inventory issue of the kit unit Inventory issue of stock component units Lot/serial tracking of kit units Applicable Not applicable Disassembly revision The revision used for assembly of a serial-tracked kit, and any revision of a non-serial-tracked kit Not applicable Sales return options A kit unit A kit unit or any kit components Sales return revision Not applicable The current revision of the kit For detailed information on kits, see Stock Kits and Non-Stock Kits. Kit Revisions To represent kits in the system, you create specifications, which define the stock and non-stock items included in a kit, by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications (IN209500) form. Each specification has at least one revision , which is automatically created when you create a specification. A revision is a version of the same kit, which has minor differences from the previous version. For example, suppose that your organization sells computers and offers a keyboard, a mouse, a leather case, and software installation service as a kit. If you change the vendor of leather cases, you can just change the inventory item for the case in the kit and instead of creating a new kit. For stock kits, you can create multiple revisions of the same specification. When you assemble a stock kit, you can use only the latest revision. If you need to disassemble a stock kit, you select the revision that was used for kit assembly. For non-stock kits, only one revision is created when you create a specification by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications form. You cannot add multiple revisions, as for stock kits. For each stock or non-stock kit revision, you can allow users to add components to the kit during assembly by selecting the Allow Component Addition check box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications form and to change the quantity of components in the kit by selecting the Allow Component Qty. Variance check box for each kit component. ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500])

Stock Kits A stock kit is a bundle of stock and non-stock components. You create each kit and add it to inventory by processing a production transaction. The kit production subtracts the stock components from inventory and adds the kit units to inventory instead. After you have assembled a kit, you can disassemble it back to its components. When a stock kit is sold, one line item appears in the transaction, and the on-hand quantity of the kit is reduced. In this topic, you will find details about the configuration, assembly, disassembly, and cost calculation of stock kits. Configuration of Stock Kits You do the following to configure a stock kit: You create item classes for kits with similar settings by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. For details, see To Create an Item Class. You create as many kits as you need by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. To indicate that each item is a kit, you select the Is a Kit check box on the General Settings tab of this form. For details, see To Create a Stock Kit. You create a specification for each kit by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications (IN209500) form. In the specification, you select the inventory items that will be included in the kit and specify the settings of each component. Any lot- and serial-tracked stock items can be added to the specification of a stock kit. For details on this step, see To Create a Specification for a Stock Kit. You create and release a kit assembly document by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN307000|IN307000]) Kit Assembly (IN307000) form. For details, see To Assemble a Stock Kit. You assign sales prices to kits as follows: If you sell a limited number of kits, you assign the default prices on a per-kit basis by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. If you are selling more than ten kits, you assign multiple sales prices to kits by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AR202010|AR202010]) Sales Price Worksheets (AR202010) form. A stock kit may require a serial or lot number and an expiration date to be assigned when the kit is produced or sold, depending on the item class settings. For details on lot and serial numbers, see Lot and Serial Numbers. You can disassemble a stock kit at any time. You may want to do this, for example, when its expiration date has approached. Assembly and Disassembly of Stock Kits You must assemble a stock kit by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN307000|IN307000]) Kit Assembly (IN307000) form before you add the kit to a sales order. The kit assembly document lists the components with their quantities and costs, as determined by the kit specification. Each time a stock kit is assembled and its kit assembly document is released, the on-hand quantities of the items used as components are automatically decreased, and the on-hand quantity of the kits is increased. For details, see To Assemble a Stock Kit. On assembly of stock kits, the standard costs of the kit's non-stock components are recorded to the Expense Accrual accounts specified by the Use Inventory/Accrual Account From setting of the posting class (on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206000|IN206000]) Posting Classes (IN206000) form) of each of the non-stock components. If disassembly might be required for a stock kit (for example, because of an expiration date), it can be performed in accordance with the revision used to assemble the kit. You can create and release a disassembly document with the Disassembly operation selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN307000|IN307000]) Kit Assembly form. The quantity of components extracted from the kit is estimated using the disassembly coefficient specified for each stock component. However, the quantities of stock components and non-stock components are not validated in any way, and you can manually adjust the calculated quantities. For details about how to disassemble a stock kit, see To Disassemble a Stock Kit. Cost Calculation For Stock Kits The assembly of stock kits (with valuation methods other than the standard cost method) creates a new cost layer. The cost of a stock kit is calculated based on the costs of components when the document is released. The total cost of the kit is the total cost of stock components according to the specification's revision, the cost of components added during assembly, and the rates of non-stock components of the Labor and Service types multiplied by their quantities. If the standard cost method is used for the stock kit, any difference between the currently effective standard cost and the total cost of components is recorded (as with non-stock kits) to the Standard Cost Variance account determined by the posting class of the stock kit. When a stock kit is disassembled, the costs of its stock components, which are returned to inventory, are calculated depending on the valuation method of the components as follows: Average : The cost of the component is calculated based on the setting of the Avg. Default Returns Cost box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form. By default, this setting is the average cost of the item at the warehouse. You can also select the last cost as the value of this box. FIFO : The cost of the component is calculated based on the setting of the FIFO Default Returns Cost box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses form. By default, this setting is the average cost of the item at the warehouse. You can also select the last cost as the value of this box. Specific : The cost of the component is the average cost of the item at the warehouse. If there is no average cost of the item at the warehouse, the last cost of the item at the warehouse is used. Standard : The cost of the component is the standard cost of the item at the warehouse, if any standard cost is defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. Otherwise, the global standard cost of the item defined on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form is used. Non-Stock Kits A non-stock kit is a bundle of stock and non-stock components; you assign an individual inventory identifier to the non-stock kit, and it can be selected in sales orders. Non-stock kits are virtual kits because they neither produced nor tracked in inventory, unlike stock kits. The stock components of the non-stock kit remain in inventory and can be sold in the kit or as separate units. In this topic, you will read about the configuration, processing, and cost calculation of non-stock kits. Configuration of Non-Stock Kits When you create a non-stock kit, you do the following: If you need to create a number of kits with similar settings, you create an item class for each group of kits by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. For details, see To Create an Item Class. You create as many kits as you need by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form. To indicate that an item is a kit, you select the Is a Kit check box on the General Settings tab of this form. For details, see To Create a Non-Stock Kit. You create a specification for each kit by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications (IN209500) form. In the specification, you select the inventory items that will be included in the kit and specify the settings of each component. Any lot- and serial-tracked stock items can be added to the specification of a non-stock kit, except for items with the When Used assignment method or with the User-Enterable issue method specified for their lot/serial classes on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN207000|IN207000]) Lot/Serial Classes (IN207000) form. For details on this step, see To Create a Specification for a Non-Stock Kit. You assign sales prices to kits as follows: If you sell a limited number of kits, you assign the default prices on a per-kit basis by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items form. If you are selling more than ten kits, you assign multiple sales prices to kits by using the ([~/?ScreenId=AR202010|AR202010]) Sales Price Worksheets (AR202010) form. Processing of Non-Stock Kits As with non-stock items, non-stock kits are not stocked. When non-stock kits are added to a sales order, the items are gathered for the sale but no preliminary assembly has been performed. When a non-stock kit is listed on a sales order as a line item, its stock components are specified on a pick list and shipped to the customer. Upon shipment confirmation, the quantity of stock components is decreased while the quantities of non-stock components and kits are not tracked in any way. On release of a Sales Order invoice for a non-stock kit with stock components, the system generates an inventory issue; on release of the inventory issue, the system debits the COGS accounts of the stock components, thus updating the stock components' costs. On the sale of a non-stock kit with only non-stock components, no inventory issue is generated. When you process a sale of a non-stock kit, its stock components are issued from inventory, and the sales revenue from all components of the kit is recorded to accounts. Calculation of Cost for Non-Stock Kits The cost of a non-stock kit may include the cost of the kit itself and the costs of all stock components included in the kit. You can select one of the following cost calculation rules on in the Cost Calculation Basis for Non-Stock Kits box on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO101000|SO101000]) Sales Orders Preferences (SO101000) form: Stock Component Cost : The system will use the sum of the costs of the kit's stock components as the cost of a non-stock kit. You can select this rule if the kit does not include non-stock components or the value of the included non-stock components is very low. Non-Stock Kit Standard Cost : The system will use the standard current cost of the non-stock kit. You can select this rule if the kit does not include stock components or the value of the included stock components is very low. Non-Stock Kit Standard Cost Plus Stock Component Cost : The system will calculate the sum of the standard current cost of a non-stock kit and the costs of the stock components of this kit. You can enter the kit standard cost directly in the Pending Cost box on the Price/Cost Information tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202000|IN202000]) Non-Stock Items (IN202000) form when you create or modify the non-stock kit. Only the Standard Cost valuation method may be assigned to non-stock kits. For more information, see Item Costs and Valuation Methods. To Create a Specification for a Stock Kit Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications (IN209500) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Kit Inventory ID box of the Summary area, select the stock kit for which you want to create a specification. In the Revision box, type the identifier of the kit revision, which is unique for the kit. Optional: In the Description box, type a description of the kit specification that will help users to identify it. Make sure that the Active check box is selected. If you want to allow users to add components to the kit during assembly or shipping, select the Allow Component Addition check box. On the Stock Components tab, do the following for each stock item you want to add to the kit: On the table toolbar, click Add Row to add a new stock component. In the Component ID column, select a stock item to be added to the kit. In the UOM column, make sure that a correct unit of measure for the item is selected. In the Component Qty. column, specify the quantity of the stock item to be assembled to the kit. If you want to allow the quantity of the stock item to vary in the kit, select the Allow Component Qty. Variance check box and specify the minimum and maximum quantity in the Min. Component Qty. and Max. Component Qty. columns correspondingly. Optional: In the Disassembly Coeff. column, specify a decimal value between 0 and 1 that will indicate to what extent the component can be returned to the inventory during disassembly. Optional: Select the Allow Component Substitution check box to indicate that the stock item can be substituted in the kit. Optional: On the Non-Stock Components tab, do the following for each non-stock item you want to add to the kit: On the table toolbar, click Add Row to add a new non-stock component. In the Component ID column, select the non-stock item to be added to the kit. In the UOM column, make sure that the correct unit of measure for the item is selected. In the Component Qty. column, specify the quantity of the stock item to be added to the kit. If you want to allow the quantity of the stock item to vary in the kit, select the Allow Component Qty. Variance check box, and specify the minimum and maximum quantity in the Min. Component Qty. and Max. Component Qty. columns, respectively. On the form toolbar, click Save . To Assemble a Stock Kit If you want stock kits to be on hand in a warehouse, you need to assemble the required quantity of the kits by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN307000|IN307000]) Kit Assembly (IN307000) form, as described in this topic. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Make sure that the specification for the kit you want to assembly has been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN209500|IN209500]) Kit Specifications (IN209500) form. To Assemble a Stock Kit Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN307000|IN307000]) Kit Assembly (IN307000) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Summary area, do the following: In the Type box, select Production . In the Date box, make sure that the correct business date is specified. In the Post Period box, make sure that the correct period for posting the transaction is specified. In the Inventory ID box, select the stock kit you want to assemble. The system will insert information about the stock and non-stock components on the corresponding tabs of the form. In the Revision box, select the revision of the kit specification that you want to use to assemble the kit. In the Quantity box, type the quantity of kit units you want to assemble. Optional: In the Description box, type a description of the assembly that will help users to identify it. In the Unit Cost column of the Stock Components tab, review the costs that the system has specified for the stock items. If required, correct the costs. If you have non-stock components in the kit, in the Unit Cost column of the Non-Stock Components tab, review the costs that the system has specified for the non-stock items. If required, correct the costs. On the form toolbar, click Save to save your changes. In the Summary area, clear the Hold check box. On the form toolbar, click Release to release the assembly document. On the Financial Details tab, make sure that the system has added the number of the General Ledger batch with the appropriate transactions. After you have assembled a stock kit, you can start selling it.
