Automated Replenishment With Acumatica ERP, you can configure automated replenishment to cover many possible situations. The functionality that supports automated replenishment is available only if the Inventory Replenishment feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Replenishment for stock items is performed on a per-warehouse basis. If your company has a single warehouse, it purchases inventory to replenish the stock directly in this warehouse. If your company has multiple warehouses (which is possible if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features form), your company can consolidate purchase orders created for replenishment in smaller warehouses, perform purchasing to a single large warehouse (distribution center), and then transfer the purchased quantities from this distribution center to other warehouses. In other cases, the items can be purchased only to a larger warehouse and transferred to point-of-sale warehouses as needed. Some products at specific warehouses may be purchased only if there are customer orders requesting the products. By using forecast models, you can fine-tune such parameters as safety stock, reorder point, and maximum quantities based on sales statistics. For more information, see Configuration of Automated Replenishment. Replenishment Preparation On the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form, you can view the list of items that require replenishment. To more effectively process the requests, you can select a warehouse and a planned purchase date, and view the list of applicable items requiring replenishment in this warehouse on a specified date. You can further narrow the list by a specific vendor, or you can view only the items assigned to you as a product manager or to your workgroup. You can select particular items and process them by clicking Process , or you can process all the listed items by clicking Process All on the form toolbar of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form. Conditions to Initiate Replenishment for a Stock Item To create the list of items that require replenishment, the system uses the settings specified on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form for each item at each warehouse where the item can be stocked. An item is listed on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form if the following general conditions are fulfilled: The processing date you've selected is within the time interval when the replenishment settings are effective (defined by Launch Date and Termination Date ). The available quantity is below the reorder point for this item at this warehouse. The item has one of the following sources: Purchase : The item stock should be replenished through a purchase. The system will generate a replenishment request for purchasing. By default, the preferred vendor specified on the Vendor Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form will be used on the order, but you can select another vendor. Transfer : The quantity required for item replenishment should be transferred from a replenishment warehouse. The system will generate a replenishment request for transfer. If an item should be replenished by using the Fixed replenishment method, the system will generate a replenishment request for the following quantity: If the replenishment source is Transfer , the transfer economic order quantity (transfer EOQ). If the source is Purchase , the economic order quantity (EOQ) specified for the selected vendor on the Vendor Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. If the item should be replenished by using the Min./Max. replenishment method, the system will generate a replenishment request for the target quantity, which is calculated as follows: Target Quantity = Max. Quantity - Quantity on Hand - Quantity on Supply + Quantity on Demand The quantity on demand is calculated based on the sales orders, transfers, and kit assembly documents (of the Production type) in accordance with the method of demand calculation, which is selected in the Demand Calculation box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. If the Item Class Settings option is selected, the demand will be calculated in accordance with the availability settings specified for this item class on the General Settings tab of the same form; if the Hard Demand Only option is selected, the demand will be calculated as Qty. SO Allocated + Qty. SO Shipped + Qty. SO Back-Ordered . The quantity on supply is calculated based on purchase receipts, transfer receipts, and kit assembly documents (of the Disassembly type) according to the availability settings specified for this item's class. The replenishment quantities on the list appear adjusted for low seasons defined by your system's set of seasonality settings. By using seasonality settings, you can adjust the quantities for replenishment that are initiated during low seasons, each of which is defined by its starting and ending date. For a purchase date within a low season, the replenishment quantity is calculated with a decreasing factor , which is a factor that appropriately decreases replenishment quantities. Replenishment Request Handling When you process the items listed on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form, the system is prompted to create appropriate replenishment requests, which are internal Acumatica ERP documents used as the basis for creating purchase and transfer orders. Replenishment requests have reference numbers, which are determined by the numbering sequence specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. The system handles replenishment requests differently based on the item replenishment source: Purchase : Replenishment requests for items with this replenishment source appear on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form, which you can use to create one order for all items to be purchased from a specific vendor. The system will perform any needed conversions to purchase units. If the Min./Max. method has been chosen for the item, the system computes the replenishment quantity as the difference between the maximum quantity and the quantity on hand, minus the quantity on supply (the quantity of items on unreleased purchase orders, purchase receipts, and quantities in transit), and plus the quantity on demand (on customer released and unreleased orders). If the Fixed Order Quantity method has been selected, the system uses the EOQ values specified for the selected vendor. Transfer : (This type of source is available only if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form.) Replenishment requests for items with this replenishment source appear on the ([~/?ScreenId=SO509000|SO509000]) Create Transfer Orders (SO509000) form. You create transfer orders to move the products from the replenishment warehouse to the warehouse when the item needs replenishment. Calculation of the Final Replenishment Quantities The quantities specified on the purchase order may differ from those specified on the replenishment requests. The final replenishment quantity for an item on a purchase order is calculated based on the settings provided for the vendor that will fulfill replenishment, and the following changes may occur: If the quantity required by replenishment settings is less than the minimum order quantity, the system uses the minimum order quantity. If the quantity required by replenishment settings exceeds the maximum order quantity, the system uses the maximum order quantity. (The maximum order quantity is not used in the current version.) If the requested quantity is not divisible by the lot size, the result is rounded up to the next integer, and that number of lots is ordered. Configuration of Automated Replenishment To be competitive, a company must strike a balance with its inventory levels: The company should not overstock inventory, because this ties up working capital, yet it should avoid stockouts, which result in lost customers and diminished customer loyalty. With Acumatica ERP, you can configure automatic replenishment for stock items at a single warehouse, or at multiple warehouses (if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form). If your warehouses may be used only for sales, you can configure the system so that the warehouses from which sales are performed will be replenished from the warehouses where purchases are performed (from distribution centers). Before you start to configure automated replenishment in your system, thoroughly consider the warehouse functions in your system, including which warehouses will perform consolidated purchasing, which will serve as replenishment sources for other warehouses, which will be replenished by transfers, and which will be replenished by direct purchasing. For more information about replenishment, see Automated Replenishment. Configuration Steps To reduce time that would be spent typing replenishment settings for each item in each warehouse, you can configure default replenishment settings at multiple levels. In general, you perform the following steps to configure automated replenishment: You create the appropriate replenishment classes, which group warehouses by the replenishment sources used in your company. For details, see To Create a Replenishment Class. You create replenishment seasonality entities. For details, see To Create a Replenishment Seasonality. You assign each warehouse to a replenishment class. For details, see To Assign a Replenishment Class to a Warehouse. For each item class, you specify replenishment settings for all replenishment classes, including the applicable seasonality settings. For details, see To Set Up Replenishment for an Item Class. For each stock item, you review the replenishment settings that are the default values from the item class, and make any needed adjustments. For details, see To Set Up Replenishment for a Stock Item. For each stock item at each specific warehouse, you review the replenishment settings that are the default values from the item. Adjust these settings for each warehouse if needed. For details, see To Specify Warehouse-Specific Replenishment Settings for a Stock Item. The sections below provide information that will help you execute these steps. Replenishment Classes Replenishment classes categorize warehouses by their replenishment source —that is, how stock is replenished at the warehouse. You assign a replenishment class to every warehouse. You create replenishment classes by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form; for each class, you specify its name, description, and replenishment source. As the replenishment source, you can select one of the following options: None : No replenishment is required for a warehouse. This option could be used, for example, for a warehouse that is closing its operations. Purchase : The items for stock replenishment in the warehouse will be purchased from vendors when it is determined by the replenishment settings and in the quantities calculated based on the replenishment settings. Transfer : For stock replenishment in a warehouse, the items will be transferred from a source warehouse; transfer orders will be generated automatically. This option is available only if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form. Purchase to Order : In warehouses with this replenishment source option selected, no actual replenishment is performed; the items are purchased only when customer orders have been received and strictly in the quantities requested by the orders. When you add an item from this warehouse to a sales order, the system automatically selects the Mark for PO check box so that a purchase order for this item can be created. Drop-Shipment : In warehouses with this replenishment source option selected, no actual replenishment is performed; the items are purchased only when customer orders have been received and strictly in the quantities requested by the orders. When you add an item from this warehouse to a sales order, the system automatically selects the Mark for PO check box so that a purchase order for the item can be created; the purchased item is sent directly to the customer. For automated replenishment, only replenishment classes with Purchase or Transfer as replenishment sources can be used. Setting Up Default Values To make it easier to provide replenishment settings for each item that are specific to each warehouse where the item is stocked, you can set up default values at multiple levels: Item class: By using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, on the Replenishment Settings tab, you specify the replenishment settings to be used as the default settings for items of the class. If you know that items of the class are stocked at multiple warehouses with different replenishment sources, configure how the items are typically replenished for each replenishment class. For each item class, you specify the following information: The method of demand calculation, which you select in the Demand Calculation box. If you select Hard Demand Only , the demand will be calculated as Qty. SO Allocated + Qty. SO Shipped + Qty. SO Back-Ordered . If you select Item Class Settings , the demand will be calculated in accordance with the availability settings specified for this item class on the General Settings tab of the same form. The seasonality. The replenishment method: None , Min/Max , or Fixed Reorder Qty . For the second or third option, specify the parameter (the reorder point quantity) required to determine the need for replenishment. The demand forecast model and parameters for the model (the period type, number of periods to analyze, and service level). The launch and termination dates of the period when the settings are effective for the class. The default replenishment settings for a newly created item class are those from the parent item class. If the created item class has no parent, the default replenishment settings are those of the class that is specified in the Default Stock Item Class box (if you are creating a stock item class) or the Default Non-Stock Item Class box (if you are creating a non-stock item class) box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN101000|IN101000]) Inventory Preferences (IN101000) form. Stock item: On the Replenishment Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you can view the replenishment settings of a particular item, which by default are provided by the item class. For the item, you can review the replenishment settings for different replenishment classes that might be used if the item is stocked at multiple warehouses, and override the settings if needed. Subitem: If subitems are used in your system, on the Replenishment Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form, you should specify parameters for each subitem. If only the default subitem is used with for the item, you specify the parameters for this default subitem; if different subitems of the item require different replenishment quantities, you specify the parameters that are different. Subitems inherit all other replenishment settings from the item. Replenishment Settings for an Item at a Particular Warehouse The many replenishment settings for all items at all warehouses are filled in with default values. On the Replenishment Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, you can review the replenishment parameters to be used for the particular item at the selected warehouse. These settings come from the item settings but can be overridden for this item stocked in a particular warehouse. For the item, you cannot use a replenishment source other than the one specified for the warehouse where the item is stocked. Also, you can override the values of the replenishment parameters used for particular subitems, if in this warehouse they differ from the default values specified for subitems on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. Configuration of Consolidated Purchasing for Replenishment With Acumatica ERP, you can configure replenishment for a number of warehouses that is performed by centralized purchasing to one large warehouse, a distribution center, and by transfers to smaller warehouses—this ensures that purchasing is performed more efficiently. You have to make sure that for items in the warehouse (which is a distribution center), Purchase is selected as the replenishment source on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form with no replenishment warehouse selected. For items in the smaller warehouses (which should be replenished by purchasing to a distribution center), you specify Purchase as the replenishment source and select the distribution center as the replenishment warehouse on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details form. First, you must prepare replenishment requests for small warehouses by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form and generate transfer orders requesting replenishment by using the form. After that, you will be able to generate purchase orders on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form—the system will create a single purchase order for all the requested quantities of each item. Additionally, you can run the process of preparing replenishment in the distribution center before you generate consolidated purchase orders for smaller warehouses, to add to consolidated purchase orders the quantities requested for replenishment in the distribution center. Upon receipt of the items (once receipts are released), you will be able to replenish the stock in the distribution center and to fulfill transfer orders by the appropriate number of shipments to all the demand warehouses. If the item is replenished by using the Purchase to Order source, for each warehouse where the item is stocked, you can specify the same replenishment warehouse. Then, when you generate purchase orders on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders form, the system will create a single purchase order for all the requested quantities of the item, no matter what are the demand warehouses. After you create a receipt for the merchandise from a vendor for this purchase order and release it, the system automatically generates transfer orders to split the received quantity between demand warehouses according to the quantities on the original sales orders. Configuration of Replenishment by Transfers If the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can configure replenishment for a number of warehouses that is performed by transfers from one large warehouse, a distribution center, for which centralized purchasing is performed, and perform purchasing efficiently. For items in the smaller warehouses that should be replenished by transfers from the distribution center, specify Transfer as the replenishment source, while for the same items stocked in the distribution center, select Purchase as the replenishment source. First, you must prepare replenishment for small warehouses by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000) form and generate transfer orders requesting replenishment—this will create demand for replenishment in the distribution center. After that, you will be able to generate replenishment requests for the distribution center. The next stage in the replenishment process is generating purchase orders on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (PO505000) form—the system will create a single purchase order for all the requested quantities of each item. Upon receipt of the items (once receipts are released), you will be able to fulfill transfer orders by appropriate number of shipments. Replenishment Methods and Their Parameters With Acumatica ERP, you can assign different replenishment methods to different items of inventory stocked at a single warehouse or different warehouses and specify warehouse-specific parameters for these methods. Different items may require different parameters because of different customer demand for them and different numbers of days required to receive the requested quantities from the vendors. You can use either of the following replenishment methods: Min./Max. or Fixed Order Qty . For each stock item, the system uses the specified method to calculate the quantities required to replenish the stock of this item, based on the replenishment parameters that you specify on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form. The available replenishment methods and their parameters are discussed in the sections below. Min./Max. Method You use the Min./Max. method to maintain the stock level of an inventory item at a particular warehouse between the specified minimum and maximum quantities. To use this method for an item, you should specify the following parameters: Maximum Quantity : This is the maximum stock quantity allowed for the item at the warehouse. Safety Stock : This is the additional stock of the item maintained to avoid stockouts. A safety stock is required if there are fluctuations in demand and supply. Because safety stock is not used in calculation for this method, add the quantity of the safety stock to both maximum quantity and reorder point quantity . Reorder Point : The system uses the reorder point quantity in the Min./Max. replenishment method rather than a minimum quantity. The quantity to be used as the minimum quantity is specified in the Reorder Point column on Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Generally, the reorder point quantity would be estimated as the quantity that may be required during the lead time (the time when the product is being shipped from the vendor location to your company). If you need to maintain safety stock, include the safety stock quantity in the reorder point quantity. Once the system detects that current stock level (the available quantity) of the particular item has reached or fallen below the reorder point, it calculates the quantity required to replenish the item stock up to the maximum quantity by adding the quantity on demand to the difference between quantities of the maximum, on hand, and on supply. You control the way the system calculates the quantities on demand for classes of stock items by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN204500) form as follows: Hard Demand Only : For all stock items of the class, the demand is calculated as (Qty.SO Allocated) + (Qty SO Back-Ordered) + (Qty SO Shipped) Item Class Settings : For all stock items of the class, the demand is calculated in accordance with the availability options selected for the item class on the General Settings tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes form. Fixed Order Quantity Method You use the Fixed Order Quantity method when you want to replenish the item stock with a fixed quantity each time it falls below the reorder point. This method uses the following parameters: Fixed Quantity : We recommend that you use as the fixed quantity the economical order quantity (EOQ) determined by warehouse specialists for a particular item by estimating the cost of ordering the item from a particular vendor. For each vendor from which the stock item can be purchased, the EOQ is specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=PO201000|PO201000]) Vendor Inventory (PO201000) form. You can view EOQs specified for all vendors of the item on the Vendor Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form. Safety Stock : This is the additional stock of the item maintained to avoid stockouts. The safety stock is required if there are fluctuations in demand and supply. Reorder Point : For this method, too, the reorder point is specified as the safety stock plus the quantity that may be required during the lead time. With the Fixed Order Quantity method, the system generates request for the economical order quantity (EOQ) for the item once it determines that the available quantity reaches or is lower than the reorder point. Parameter Estimation For automated replenishment, you can manually enter estimates of replenishment parameters—such as safety stock, maximum quantity, and reorder point—that were made externally by logistics specialists for each item. Alternatively, you can configure the system to automatically calculate the replenishment parameters. In Acumatica ERP, you can use demand forecast models to calculate replenishment parameters by using sales statistics. For overview of the functionality, see Replenishment Parameters Based on Demand Forecast . With this flexibility, you can lower carrying costs, avoid stockouts, minimize excess or obsolete inventory, improve cash flow, and increase customer loyalty levels. Other Item-Specific Parameters The parameters described below are also used in automated replenishment for the inventory item at the specific warehouse: Launch and Termination Dates : These dates define the range during which the replenishment settings specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form will affect the item if it is stocked at this warehouse. By default, the dates come from the item settings (which are specified on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form but can be overridden for the item at the specific warehouse). Vendor Details : To replenish the stock of the inventory item at the warehouse, you should specify the vendor from which inventory will be purchased. The system uses the default vendor of the inventory item (as specified on the Vendor Details tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items form) unless you have selected another vendor for the item at the warehouse. The following item-specific parameters are associated with the selected preferred vendor: The lead time required to ship the item from the vendor location to the warehouse The lot size, if specified, which rounds up the order quantity for the mix/max method to multiples of lot size The minimum order frequency (the minimum number of days between two successive orders) The minimum and maximum order quantity The EOQ Subitem Details If your company uses subitems in your implementation of Acumatica ERP, you can also specify the replenishment parameters for each subitem of the item stored at the warehouse. On the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, you can generate the list of all subitems of the inventory item. By default, all subitems have the same parameter values, copied from the values for the default subitem. On the Subitem Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, you can create a list of subitems stocked at the warehouse and specify replenishment parameters for each subitem. Separate replenishment quantities will be calculated for each subitem, based on subitem-specific parameters and the current quantity on hand (of the item with this subitem) at the warehouse. Replenishment Parameters Based on Demand Forecast Businesses strive to have enough stock for potential sales. Replenishing the stock in time and in the proper quantities helps businesses to retain customers while reducing storage costs. For an overview of the automated replenishment functionality implemented in Acumatica ERP, see Automated Replenishment. To predict the demand—that is, the stock level you may need in the future for each item—you can use demand forecast methods. The current version of Acumatica ERP uses the moving average method, one of the simplest methods. In Acumatica ERP, you can use the predicted average daily demand, calculated with the help of demand forecasting models, to periodically update the values of replenishment parameters (such as maximum quantity, reorder point, and safety stock) in order to more precisely calculate the quantities required for replenishment. Using the Moving Average Method With the moving average method, you calculate the demand for a specific future period based on historical sales data for multiple consecutive periods in the immediate past. This method works well for items with specific trends in sales or with stable sales not subjected to random significant fluctuations. To apply the moving average method to forecasting demand, you select the specific time period (a week, a month, or a quarter) and the number of these periods to analyze the data, depending on how the sales of the particular product or group of products (implemented in Acumatica ERP as an item class) change over time. This forecast model uses the data available for the specified number of past periods to forecast demand for the period immediately following the last period whose data is used in forecasting. If you select a month as the forecast period and want to perform a forecast on the 15th day of the current month, 15 days' worth of data will not be used for forecasting; only data from full periods is used. The system calculates the daily demand for the nearest future period based on daily sales in all days of the specified number of prior periods. As the actual data for the last forecast period becomes available, you can forecast the demand for the next period by using the data of the previous periods shifted by one period. This method smooths out the data; the more periods you use to calculate the average demand, the greater the smoothing effect. The average lead time is calculated for each stock item‒preferred vendor pair based on all purchase orders in the system history. The average lead time is computed as average difference (on all orders) between the date when an order is created (the Requested on date) and the date of the receipt created for the goods listed on the order. Using Seasonality Parameters for Forecasting The sales of some products follow certain cycles or patterns. For example, the peak of ski sales is in the winter. These patterns in sales can be described as seasonality . A set of seasonality settings is a list of low and high seasons with appropriate factors (coefficients) that show how sales decline or increase in each of these specific seasons, as compared to average sales volumes calculated over all time. The seasons for particular products or groups of products with similar sales behavior and corresponding factors can be determined by analyzing sales data spanning several financial years. You define seasonality settings by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206600|IN206600]) Replenishment Seasonality (IN206600) form. The seasons for one seasonality should not intersect. For date ranges not included in any season, the factor is 1.0 by default. A low season for groups of products may span multiple financial periods or be contained in a single financial period. The seasonality settings are used as follows: The system normalizes the historical data available for the specified seasons. The sales volumes for each day of a season are deleted by the appropriate factor to calculate the sales quantities as though it were a normal season. The system calculates the average daily sales quantity based on the historical data of the specified number of periods. For seasons within the specified periods, the system uses the normalized data. The standard deviation for the daily demand is calculated for actual sales data, not for normalized data. The average daily sales quantity is adjusted for seasons if seasons are expected within the forecast period. The average daily sales is multiplied by the average seasonality factor (calculated over all days in the forecast period—normal days and days of seasons). Calculating Replenishment Parameters By using the calculated average daily demand (daily sales), average lead time, and their standard deviation values, the system computes the following parameters used in automated replenishment: Reorder Point and Safety Stock . (ReorderPoint) = (AverageDailyDailyDemand)*(AverageLeadTime) + (SafetyStock) The safety stock is calculated as follows to address possible fluctuations in demand (daily sales): (SafetyStock) = Normsinv (ServiceLevel)* SQRT((AverageLeadTime * STDEV(DailyDemand))^2 + (AverageDailyDemand * STDEV(LeadTime))^2) To understand this calculation, note the following: AverageDailyDemand is the average daily demand (average daily sales), calculated as the item quantity on all sales orders, credit memos, transfers out, and kit assembly documents in all the time periods used to analyze the data divided by the number of days. STDEV(DailyDemand) is the standard deviation of daily demand (daily sales quantity) from the average quantity. AverageLeadTime is the average lead time (in days) calculated based on the purchases in all the time periods used to analyze the data. STDEV(LeadTime) is the standard deviation of lead time (in days) from the average value. Normsinv(ServiceLevel) is the service factor, which is calculated based on the service level specified as a percentage. The service level is used to optimize the safety stock level. Generally, it is set on the item-class level, but it can be specified for each item in each warehouse if needed. The service level represents the probability of stockout not being reached. The Normsinv(ServiceLevel) function provides the factor that adjusts the safety stock required for the specified service level. With the service level selected at 50%, the safety stock is zero (that is, not required). The factor reaches 1.0 with the service level approximately 84%, which is the default value for the service level on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form. To maintain a higher service level, you will need a safety stock that exceeds the calculated quantity. For an example of the calculation of the replenishment parameters for the moving average method, see An Example of Replenishment Parameter Calculation. The Maximum Stock is set equal to Reorder Point ; if needed, you can manually increase the value of Maximum Stock . Setting Up Parameter Calculation You specify the forecast method and its parameters for each item class by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, and then the settings are used as default values for items of the class. You can select values that differ from the default ones for particular items of the class by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Moreover, if the Multiple Warehouses feature is enabled on the ([~/?ScreenId=CS100000|CS100000]) Enable/Disable Features (CS100000) form, you can adjust the replenishment settings for each warehouse in which the items are stocked. Splitting Parameters by Subitems If subitems are used in your system, you can use demand forecasting to calculate replenishment parameters for specific subitems of the items if having enough stock for these subitems is important to your business. For such items, on the Replenishment Info tab of the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form, specify the initial replenishment parameters for each of the subitems used. After that, the system will calculate parameters for each listed subitem by using the forecasted daily demand (daily sales) for the specific subitem. All subitems of the item should be listed in the Subitem Replenishment Parameters table. If specific subitems do not require replenishment, specify zero values as their parameters. Updating Replenishment Parameters by Using Forecast-based Values You use the following Acumatica ERP forms to update replenishment parameters and then prepare the replenishment: ([~/?ScreenId=IN508500|IN508500]) Calculate Replenishment Parameters (IN508500): You use this form to compute the average daily sales and average lead time, and then to calculate the following parameters used in automated replenishment: Max. Qty. , Reorder Point , and Safety Stock . ([~/?ScreenId=IN509500|IN509500]) Apply Replenishment Parameters (IN509500): On this form, you review the parameter values suggested by the forecast and replace the old values of replenishment parameters with the suggested (calculated) ones. You can manually adjust the suggested parameters if needed. ([~/?ScreenId=IN508000|IN508000]) Prepare Replenishment (IN508000): You use this form to find the items that need replenishment and to calculate replenishment quantities for these items. ([~/?ScreenId=PO505000|PO505000]) Create Purchase Orders (IN505000): You can use this form to generate purchase orders for items requiring replenishment. Availability Calculation The on-hand quantities of items at warehouses are automatically updated only after the documents that record inventory transactions are released and posted. On-hand quantities usually differ from actually available quantities because documents can be processed later than actual operations with items have been performed: certain quantities of items can be booked on on-hold sales orders, picked for shipping but not shipped, returned from customers before returns are created, received from vendors with receipts not yet released. Acumatica ERP gives you real-time visibility into available inventory, thus improving customer service. You can configure the way availability data is calculated in accordance with your company's policies. You define the availability calculation rules on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form. For each item class, on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes (IN201000) form, you need to specify the particular calculation rule that defines the availability calculation options for this item class. Types of Quantities Calculated The available quantities of items are calculated at the location level. Some warehouse locations may hold some quantities of damaged or returned items, and those quantities generally cannot be used for sale and should not be included in the quantities available. If the Multiple Warehouse Locations feature is disabled in your system, all the quantities available for a single default location of each warehouse are included in the availability data. For more information, see Warehouse Locations. For each item, the quantities summarized below are maintained in the system and available for viewing on any form where you select a stock item for adding to the document. Element Description Quantity On Hand This is the on-hand quantity is the quantity of items (expressed in the base unit of measure) that are physically in stock and immediately available. The on-hand quantity of items is affected only by released documents. If the Allow Negative Quantity check box is selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes form, Acumatica ERP allows a negative on-hand quantity for items of the class. Warnings are issued on transactions that will result in negative inventory quantities. A location-level negative quantity can occur due to errors on inventory documents—incorrect quantities specified or wrong locations—or delayed release of receipt or transfer documents confirming the actual arrival of goods. Physical inventory can be undertaken for items with negative on-hand quantities. Quantity Not Available For each location in a warehouse, you can specify whether quantities at the location will be included in the quantity available. For example, items should not be included in quantities available for locations dedicated to items that are consigned, damaged, returned, or in need of repair. If the Include in Qty. Available option is selected for the location on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204000|IN204000]) Warehouses (IN204000) form, the quantities available at the location will be added to the quantity available; if the option is not selected, those quantities will be added to the quantity not available. As a result, for each warehouse, the total quantities available and unavailable are calculated as the sum of respective quantities for all warehouse locations. Total Addition and Total Deduction The ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details (IN402000) inquiry form shows Total Addition and Total Deduction , which have values calculated based on unreleased documents with various statuses. Total Addition is the quantity of base units of the inventory item on unreleased purchase orders, receipts, and incoming transfers. For each item class, you can specify which of the listed quantities should be included in this value for items of the class. See the Options Affecting Available Quantities section below for the entire list of availability options. Total Deduction is the quantity of base units of the inventory item on unreleased sales orders, inventory issues, shipments, transfers, and kit assembly documents, plus the non-available quantity. For each item class, you can specify which of the listed quantities should be included in the total deduction quantity for items of the class in accordance with policies established in your organization. Quantity Available For each item, the quantity available is calculated as Quantity on Hand + Total Addition - Total Deduction . This value is calculated in accordance with the options selected on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201000|IN201000]) Item Classes form for the item class. See the Options Affecting Available Quantities section below for the entire list of availability options. Quantity Available for Shipping This quantity is calculated by the system as the on-hand quantity with quantities on issues, quantities shipped, and quantities allocated deducted. This calculation is not affected by any options selected by users. Options Affecting Available Quantities For each item class, you can select an availability calculation rule to define how you want the system to calculate the available quantities for items of the class. Each availability calculation rule, which you create on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN201500|IN201500]) Availability Calculation Rules (IN201500) form, defines the options listed below. Documents with the Released and Posted statuses do not affect calculation of these quantities. Option Description Deduct Qty. on Issues If selected, indicates that the system for each item of the class will deduct the quantities on issues from the quantities available at the location. Deduct Qty. on Sales Prepared If selected, indicates that the system will deduct the quantities of the item on sales orders (of the SO , IN , and CS types) with the On Hold , Credit Hold , Pending Approval , and Rejected statuses from the available quantity. The quantity of each item on sales orders with these statuses is shown in the SO Prepared box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Deduct Qty. on Sales Orders If selected, indicates that the system will deduct the quantities of the items of this class on open sales orders (of the SO type) from the available quantity. The quantity of the item on open sales orders of the SO type is shown in the SO Booked box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Deduct Qty. Shipped If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will deduct the shipped quantities from the available quantity of the item. The quantity of the item on open sales orders of the CS and IN types is shown in the SO Shipped box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Deduct Qty. Allocated If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will deduct the quantities on unconfirmed shipments, the quantities of the item on sales orders of the SA type, and those quantities on sales orders of the SO type with On Hold , Credit Hold , Pending Approval , Rejected , and Open statuses that were specifically allocated (reserved). This quantity of the item is shown in the SO Allocated box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Deduct Qty. of Kit Assembly Demand If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will deduct the quantities used for kit production according to kit assembly documents. If items are listed on disassembly documents, their quantities (with disassembly coefficients taken into account) will be added to the available quantities. Deduct Qty. on Back Orders If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will deduct the quantities of the item on sales orders with the Back Order status. Deduct Qty. on Service Orders Prepared If selected, indicates that the quantities of items on service orders with the On Hold status are deducted (for items of the class) from the available quantities of these items. The item quantity on service orders with this status is shown in the FS Prepared box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Deduct Qty. on Service Orders If selected, indicates that the quantities of items on service orders with the Open status are deducted (for items of the class) from the available quantities of these items. The item quantity on these service orders is shown in the FS Booked box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Deduct Qty. Allocated for Service Orders If selected, indicates that the quantities that were specifically allocated for service orders are deducted (for items of the class) from the available quantities of these stock items. The item quantity on these service orders is shown in the FS Allocated box on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN402000|IN402000]) Inventory Allocation Details form. Include Qty. on Receipts If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will add the quantities of the item on inventory receipts to the quantity available. Include Qty. In-Transit If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will add the quantities of the item that are in transit (and not yet received at the destination warehouses) to the quantity available. Include Qty. on PO Receipts If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will add the quantities of the item on unreleased purchase receipts to the quantity available. Include Qty. on Purchase Prepared If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will add the quantities of the item listed on purchase orders with the On Hold , Pending Approval statuses to the quantity available. Include Qty. on Purchase Orders If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will add the quantities of the item listed on open purchase orders to the quantity available. Include Qty. of Kit Assembly Supply If selected, indicates that for each item (that is a kit) of the class, the system will add the quantities of the kits assembled and included in the kit assembly documents to the quantity available. The quantities of disassembled kits according to the kit assembly documents will be deducted from the quantity available. Include Qty. on Sales Returns If selected, indicates that for each item of the class, the system will add the quantities of the item listed on returns to the Quantity Available of the item. In particular, the quantities on return orders with the On Hold and Pending Approval statuses will be deducted from the SO Prepared quantities; the quantities on return orders in the Open status will be deducted from the SO Booked quantities; the quantities on unconfirmed shipments (with the Receipt operation) will be deducted from the SO Allocated quantities; the quantities on confirmed shipments (with the Receipt operation) will be deducted from the SO Shipped quantities. Thus, the quantities on shipments (with the Receipt operation) decrease the Total Deduction quantities. An Example of Replenishment Parameter Calculation Suppose that on March 1, ABC company first purchased a new gadget for bikers (the New Gadget stock item) and sold it to a local sporting goods store, Best Sports. Best Sports decided to order 200 units during April and May. The ABC company's purchasing manager, who is responsible for sales of the New Gadget item, decided to use the following default replenishment parameters during these three months of sales: Safety Stock : 20 Reorder Point : 50 Max Quantity: 200 These parameters were specified for the New Gadget stock item on the Replenishment Info tab on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form. Before extending the sales to other customers, the purchasing manager has decided to collect the relevant sales data during the first three months and then calculate the replenishment parameters based on this data using the following settings: Forecast Type : Month Periods to Analyze : 3 Launch Date : March 1 The purchasing manager tracks the New Gadget related events and collects the data as follows. Timeline of purchasing, receiving, and replenishing New Gadget Business Date Business Event March March 1 ABC company prepares replenishment for New Gadget. March 1 Purchase order for 200 units of New Gadget is created, approved and sent to the New Gadget vendor. March 15 The Best Sports store places a sales order for 200 units. March 21 ABC company receives 200 units of New Gadget. Purchase receipt for 200 units is released. March 22 Shipment to the Best Sports store is confirmed. March 31 ABC company collects the data: Total Sales: 200 units; Daily Demand: 200/31=6.45; Lead Time: 20 April April 1 ABC company prepares replenishment for New Gadget. April 1 Purchase order for 200 units of New Gadget is created, approved and sent to the New Gadget vendor. April 15 The Best Sports store places a sales order for 200 units. April 18 ABC company receives 200 units of New Gadget. Purchase receipt for 200 units is released. April 22 Shipment to the Best Sports store is confirmed. April 30 ABC company collects the data: Total Sales: 200 units; Daily Demand: 200/30=6.67; Lead Time: 17 May May 1 ABC company prepares replenishment for New Gadget. May 1 Purchase order for 200 units of New Gadget is created, approved and sent to the New Gadget vendor. May 15 ABC company receives 200 units of New Gadget. Purchase receipt for 200 units is released. May 15 The Best Sports store places a sales order for 200 units. May 22 Shipment to the Best Sports store is confirmed. May 31 ABC company collects the data: Total Sales: 200 units; Daily Demand: 200/31=6.45; Lead Time: 14 June June 1 The ABC company uses the collected data to calculate the replenishment parameters. On June 1, the purchasing manager initiates the calculation of replenishment parameters by using the ([~/?ScreenId=IN508500|IN508500]) Calculate Replenishment Parameters (IN508500) form. The service level for the New Gadget stock item is selected as 90%. The system calculated the replenishment parameters as follows. Parameter Suggested Values Explanation Average Daily Demand 6.52 (200 + 200 + 200) / (31 + 30 + 31) STDEVP(Daily Demand) 0.10 STDEVP(200/31, 200/30, 200/31) Average Lead Time 17 (20 + 17 + 14 ) / 3 STDEVP(Lead Time) 2.45 STDEVP(20, 17, 14) Service Level 90% Normsinv(Service Level) 1.28 Safety Stock 20.6 1.28 * SQRT((17 * 0.1) ^ 2 + (6.52 * 2.45) ^ 2) Reorder Point 131.49 (17 * 6.52 + 20.6) Max. Quantity 131.49 As this simple example shows, the reorder point should be increased to 131 units mostly due to a rather large average lead time.

To Set Up Replenishment for a Stock Item Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN202500|IN202500]) Stock Items (IN202500) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Inventory ID box, select the stock item for which you want to configure replenishment settings. On the Replenishment Info tab, do the following for each replenishment class you want to assign to the item: In the Repl. Class column, select the replenishment class you want to assign to the stock item. In the Seasonality column, select the seasonality for the stock item. In the Method box, select the replenishment method to be applied to the stock item. In the other columns, specify replenishment parameters according to needs of your organization. Repeat the previous 4 steps for each On the Vendor Details tab, make sure that the vendors from which the stock item should be purchased have been added and that the vendors are active. On the form toolbar, click Save .

To Specify Warehouse-Specific Replenishment Settings for a Stock Item If your organization uses multiple warehouses and automated replenishment, you can set up warehouse-specific settings for the replenishment of each stock item by using ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form, as described in this topic. To open any form, you can navigate to it or search for it (by its name or by its form ID without periods). For more information about search capabilities, see Search in the Modern UI. Before You Proceed Make sure that the replenishment class you want to assign to the item at this warehouse has been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN208800|IN208800]) Replenishment Classes (IN208800) form. Make sure that the seasonality you want to assign to the item at this warehouse has been created on the ([~/?ScreenId=IN206600|IN206600]) Replenishment Seasonality (IN206600) form. To Specify Warehouse-Specific Replenishment Settings for a Stock Item Open the ([~/?ScreenId=IN204500|IN204500]) Item Warehouse Details (IN204500) form by searching for or navigating to it. In the Inventory ID box, select the stock item for which you want to specify replenishment settings. In the Warehouse box, select the warehouse. On the Replenishment Info tab, do the following: In the Replenishment Settings section, select the Override Replenishment Settings check box. In the Replenishment Source box, select the source of replenishment to apply to the stock item stored in the selected warehouse. In the Replenishment Method box, select the method of replenishment to apply to the stock item stored in the selected warehouse. In the Replenishment Warehouse box, select the warehouse that will be a source of replenishment. In the Replenishment Parameters section, specify the parameters according to business processes of your organization. To edit a parameter, you must first select the Override check box to the right of the parameter box. On the form toolbar, click Save .
